A: Mechanochemical treatment, such as milling in a planetary mill, can modify the morphology of vanadium-based catalysts, enhancing their catalytic activity and selectivity. It also increases the dispersion of the vanadium oxide active phase on the support.

Q: How does the position of vanadium ions in a catalyst affect its catalytic activity?
A: The position of vanadium ions in a catalyst, assumed in the reaction medium, depends on its redox potential and the oxidation state of the fresh catalyst. When the oxidation state of vanadium ions in the initial catalyst is higher than that corresponding to the redox potential of reaction medium, reduction of surface vanadium will take place until an equilibrium is attained.

Q: What is the role of potassium in the oxidation of SO2 to SO3 in the production of sulphuric acid?
A: In the process of SO2 to SO3 oxidation, potassium salts are used as promoting additives to the catalyst. They increase the life and activity of the catalyst at lower temperatures.

Q: How does the introduction of promoters into the basic V–P–O composition influence the properties of catalysts?
A: The introduction of promoters into the basic V–P–O composition can modify the properties of the catalysts. It is believed that on interaction with ammonia, surface oxide ions may be exchanged to NH2 groups, forming surface structural units of the type which may play the role of active sites in the ammoxidation of toluene.

Q: How does the nucleophilicity of surface oxide ions influence the catalytic activity of vanadium oxide catalysts?
A: The nucleophilicity of surface oxide ions influences the catalytic activity of vanadium oxide catalysts. A higher nucleophilicity of surface oxide ions accelerates the rate of the oxidation reaction, as it can accept electron pairs from the reacting molecules. This results in an increase in the effective negative charge on oxygen atoms, equivalent to the increase of nucleophilicity of the surface.

Q: What is the main industry that utilizes collagen?
A: Collagen and gelatin are widely used in the food, pharmaceutical, cosmetic, biomedical materials and leather industries.

Q: What is the main source of industrial collagen?
A: The main sources of industrial collagen are those from pig and bovine skin and bones.

Q: What was the yield of aquatic products in China in 2005?
A: In 2005, the yield of aquatic products in China was 51,000,000 tons, accounting for 1/3 of the worldwide total production, with the main species being carp, grass carp, silver carp and bighead carp.

Q: Why is the comprehensive utilization of freshwater fish important?
A: Comprehensive utilization of freshwater fish, especially the production of value-added products, can increase revenue for the producers and accelerate the development of aquatic culture industry. It can also help to reduce pollutions and emissions of offensive odors caused by discarded fish.

Q: What were the yields of acid-soluble collagen from different fish offal?
A: The yields of acid-soluble collagen were highest from cod skin, at around 42.5%, followed by carp skin at 41.3%, and then scales and bones, which yielded 1.35% and 1.06%, respectively.

Q: What were the main differences in the amino acid composition and degree of hydroxylation of collagens from different fish offal?
A: The amino acid composition of acid-soluble collagens showed that glycine was the major amino acid in every collagen. The imino acid contents, hydroxyproline and proline, were highest in collagens from carp skin, scale, and bone, and lowest in cod skin ASC.

Q: What is the primary reaction in the mixed alcohol synthesis (MAS) process?
A: The major reaction in the MAS process is the alcohol formation. While hydrocarbon formation and water–gas-shift reaction compose of the side reactions.

Q: What are the challenges in the mixed alcohol synthesis process?
A: The mixed alcohol technology faces challenges in achieving high catalytic activity, operating under rigorous reaction conditions, and achieving selective control of the low carbon mixed alcohols. Besides, the design of the process engineering is also important for the efficient removal of the react heat and enhancement of alcohol productivity.

Q: What are the two types of catalysts used in mixed alcohol synthesis?
A: The heterogeneous catalysts used for mixed alcohol synthesis can be broadly divided into noble metal-based and non-noble metal-based categories.

Q: What are the advantages of using molybdenum sulfides catalysts in mixed alcohol synthesis?
A: Molybdenum sulfides catalysts possess excellent sulfur tolerance and high activity for water–gas-shift reaction, making them promising catalysts for mixed alcohol synthesis. Moreover, the alkali-doped molybdenum sulfide catalysts are more attractive for commercial aspects among various MAS catalysts.

Q: How does the introduction of promoters like Co and Ni affect the performance of MoS2 catalysts in mixed alcohol synthesis?
A: The 3d transition metals, particularly F–T elements such as Co and Ni, are effective promoters to enhance the alcohol yield as well as C2 +OH selectivity of MoS2 catalysts.

Q: What is the significance of the ADM catalyst in the context of mixed alcohol synthesis?
A: The alkali-doped molybdenum sulfide catalysts, promoted by promoters like Cs and MoS2, are among the most promising catalysts for commercial applications in mixed alcohol synthesis.

Q: What are the advantages of using metal carbides as catalysts in mixed alcohol synthesis?
A: Metal carbides possess superior hydrogen adsorption, activation, and transfer capabilities, making them potential substitutes for noble metal catalysts. They have also been shown to be promising catalysts for CO hydrogenation reactions.

Q: What is the potential solution to the problem of by-product formation in mixed alcohol synthesis?
A: The comprehensive utilization of by-products such as water, hydrocarbons, and CO2 can help lower the cost of production of mixed alcohols. For instance, in the slurry-bed reactor design, the production of CO2 and by-product formation are suppressed, allowing for a higher yield and better selectivity toward higher alcohols.

Q: What is the primary role of an automotive three-way catalyst?
A: The primary role of an automotive three-way catalyst is to convert emissions of three pollutants in engine exhaust gases

Q: What is the significance of the development of an intelligent catalyst in the automotive industry?
A: The development of an intelligent catalyst aims to reduce the use of precious metals like palladium, rhodium, and platinum in automotive catalysts, thereby conserving resources and reducing costs. It also helps to adjust the demand for these metals in proportion to their natural source ratio, addressing the supply and demand issues in the automotive industries.

Q: How does the Pd-perovskite catalyst maintain its durability?
A: The Pd-perovskite catalyst maintains its durability due to its self-regenerative function, enabling it to maintain high catalytic activity even when exposed to inherent redox fluctuations, like those found in an actual engine exhaust environment.

Q: What is the impact of the intelligent catalyst on automotive emissions regulations?
A: The intelligent catalyst enables vehicles to achieve stricter emission standards, such as the Japanese Ultra-Low-Emission Vehicle (J-ULEV) and the new Super-Ultra-Low-Emission Vehicle (J-SULEV), which require significant reductions in emissions of both hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides.

Q: How does the intelligent catalyst manage the growth of precious metal particles?
A: The intelligent catalyst suppresses the growth of precious metal particles, thereby maintaining high efficiency. In particular, it reduces the need for auxiliary treatment to achieve this.

Q: What is the importance of the self-regenerative function of the precious metals in the intelligent catalyst?
A: The self-regenerative function of precious metals like palladium, rhodium, and platinum in the intelligent catalyst enables them to adapt to environmental changes, respond sensitively, and maintain high performance. This function contributes to the catalyst's durability and efficiency.

Q: How does the intelligent catalyst manage the supply and demand of precious metals?
A: The intelligent catalyst technology solves the problem of the supply and demand of precious metals for automotive applications by enabling the automotive industries to reduce their reliance on these metals. It also helps to conserve precious metals by reducing the growth of precious metal particles.

Q: What is the effect of the intelligent catalyst on the supply and demand of precious metals?
A: The development of the intelligent catalyst technology is expected to reduce the demand for precious metals like palladium, rhodium, and platinum in automotive industries. This could solve the socioeconomic problem relating to the supply and demand of these metals and potentially lower their prices.

Q: How does the intelligent catalyst respond to redox fluctuations in an engine exhaust gas?
A: The intelligent catalyst moves back and forth between the B-site in the perovskite structure and the metallic nanoparticles, responding to inherent redox fluctuations of the actual engine exhaust. This enables it to maintain its catalytic activity during the lifetime of a vehicle.

Q: What is the potential impact of the intelligent catalyst technology?
A: The intelligent catalyst technology has the potential to significantly contribute to the solution of the supply-and-demand problems of precious metals in automotive industries. It could also be an important technology not only for automobiles but also for various internal combustion engines, enabling the creation of cleaner exhaust gases.

Q: What are the potential applications of 1-D metal oxide nanomaterials?
A: 1-D metal oxide nanomaterials have potential applications in chemical sensing or biosensing due to their large surface-to-volume ratios and a Debye length comparable to their dimensions. They have been reported for use in gas sensors, humidity sensors and biosensors.

Q: Why are enzymeless electrochemical glucose sensors preferred over those that use enzymes?
A: Enzymeless electrochemical glucose sensors are preferred because they rely on the properties of electrode materials, on which glucose is oxidized directly. This approach offers reliable and fast determination of glucose without using enzymes, which are insufficiently stable regarding their nature to both pH and temperature.

Q: What is the role of CuO-NFs in the design of enzyme-free sensors?
A: In this study, we utilized CuO-NFs (CuO nanofibers) as a material for developing enzyme-free sensors for glucose determination. They provide a promising approach due to their ability to form 3-D network structure, providing a large effect electrode surface for catalytic application.

Q: What are the advantages of using glycol as a dispersant in the preparation of CuO-NFs films?
A: Glycol, with its higher viscidity and lower volatility, was found favorable to form a well-proportioned suspension of CuO-NFs than other dispersants. It resulted in a uniform CuO-NFs film on the electrode surface.

Q: How does the ultrasonic time affect the morphologies and electrochemical property of the CuO-NFs films electrode?
A: The study found that continuous breakdown of CuO-NFs occurred obviously in the sonication process. With increased ultrasonic time, the 1-D nanofibers were exfoliated to short nanofibers, and a 3-D network-like structure was no longer obtained.

Q: What is the established mechanism for the electrocatalytic oxidation of glucose at copper-based electrodes?
A: The Cu(II)–Cu(III) redox couple, dependent upon the hydroxide concentration, plays an important role in carbohydrate oxidation. Hydroxyl radicals are formed in the OH− oxidation at the Cu(III) catalytic centre during the potential window, which react with organic molecules.

Q: How does the concentration of NaOH affect the glucose electro-oxidation process at the CuO-NFs-GCE?
A: The study found that an obvious oxidative peak was obtained with increasing NaOH concentration. Therefore, a higher oxidative potential was required for glucose detection, and a potential of +0.40 V was selected for all subsequent amperometric detection.

Q: How does the CuO-NFs-GCE prevent electrode fouling?
A: The CuO-NFs-GCE prevents electrode fouling by forming an ordered 3-D network that shuttles electron between glucose and the working electrode. This enhances the electron transfer reaction of glucose, preventing the copper-based materials from conglomerating and allowing the sensor to maintain its sensitivity.

Q: What were the key characteristics of the as-prepared CuO-NFs?
A: The as-prepared CuO-NFs had a diameter ranging from 90 to 240 nm with tens of micrometers in length. They were accumulated by CuO nanoparticles with a complex pore structure, which could provide a large surface area and high surface energy for catalytic reaction.

Q: What are the most abundant air pollutions emitted from power plants, incinerators and boilers during coal combustion?
A: The most abundant air pollutions emitted from these sources are sulfur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen oxides (NOx).

Q: What is the most effective and widely used method for the removal of SO2 in utility boilers?
A: The most effective and widely used method for the removal of SO2 in utility boilers is Wet flue gas desulfurization (WFGD) technologies.

Q: How is NOx reduction in coal-fired boilers approached?
A: For the reduction of NOx in coal-fired boilers, combustion modification technologies such as low NOx burners, over fire air, reburning, and choosing low content of nitrogen coals are considered. After that, post-combustion technologies including selective catalytic reduction (SCR) and selective non-catalytic reduction (SNCR) can be applied.

Q: What is the role of ozone injection technology in air pollution control?
A: Ozone injection technology is an attractive method for removing nitrogen oxides (NOx) from flue gases. It is effective and energy-efficient compared to typical nonthermal plasma and electron beam processes.

Q: How does the ozone injection process work in relation to NOx removal?
A: When ozone is injected into the flue gas, it can oxidize NO in the flue gas into NO2, NO3, N2O5, and other high order nitrogen species which can be efficiently removed in downstream wet scrubber such as WFGD system.

Q: What role does a washing tower play in the simultaneous removal of NOx, SO2 and Hg?
A: The washing tower is used to remove NO, SO2, and elemental mercury from the flue gas. It works by using an alkaline solution washing tower, and the multi-pollution removal efficiency is investigated by the ozone injection technology.

Q: What is the ideal temperature for the ozone injection technology to be effective?
A: The ideal temperature for the ozone injection technology to be effective is believed to be lower than 473 K (Kelvin).

Q: How does the presence of SO2 impact the oxidation of NO by ozone and O radical?
A: The presence of SO2 in the reaction system does not significantly impact the conversion of NO by ozone and O radical.

Q: What is the significance of the reinforcement's properties in developing green composites?
A: The properties of the reinforcement, including its fiber morphology, structure, and chemical composition, play crucial roles in determining the quality of a composite. Therefore, understanding these properties is essential for creating environmentally friendly composites.

Q: What were the main techniques used to analyze the properties of the fabric?
A: The fabric's properties were studied using chemical analysis, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and polarized optical microscopic techniques.

Q: How did alkali treatment affect the properties of the fabric?
A: Alkali treatment led to a decrease in the hemicellulose content and an increase in the crystallinity index of the fabric. Furthermore, the thermal stability and tensile properties of the fabric increased on alkali treatment.

Q: What were the results of the chemical analysis of the untreated and alkali-treated fabrics?
A: The chemical analysis revealed that on alkali treatment, the percentage of α-cellulose increased, while that of hemicellulose decreased. This is in line with the observations made in the FT-IR analysis.

Q: How did the thermal stability of the alkali-treated fabric compare to the untreated fabric?
A: The thermal stability of the alkali-treated fabric was found to be greater than that of the untreated fabric. This is likely due to the reduction in the hemicellulose content, which decreased on alkali treatment.

Q: Can you explain how the uniaxial nature of the fibers in the fabric can be exploited?
A: The uniaxial nature of the fibers in the fabric can be exploited to control the mechanical properties of the composites. This can be achieved by proper orientation of the fabric towards the stress direction in the creation of composites.

Q: What were the comparative results of the fabric's chemical composition, moisture content, and tensile properties with other reinforcing natural fibers?
A: The fabric's chemical composition, moisture content, and tensile properties were compared with other reinforcing natural fibers like jute, flax, hemp, ramie, sisal, and coir. The fabric's moisture content was found to be only 2.3%, which is low and could facilitate good bonding of the fabric with the matrix.

Q: How does the higher modulus of the alkali-treated natural fabric make it suitable for use as reinforcement in the development of green composites?
A: The alkali-treated natural fabric has a higher modulus, which contributes to its tensile strength and stability. This makes it suitable to be used as a reinforcement in the development of green composites and for other high-value fabric applications.

Q: What are the health benefits associated with tea consumption?
A: Epidemiological studies suggest that tea consumption, particularly of green tea, offers protection against several types of cancer. This is attributed to the presence of polyphenolic compounds, particularly catechins, which can afford protection against cancer.

Q: What are the components added to boiling water to prepare kombucha tea?
A: Black tea, green tea and tea manufacture waste are added to boiling water and allowed to infuse for about 5 minutes. Sucrose (10%) is dissolved in the tea and the preparation is left to cool.

Q: How is the pH of the kombucha tea changed during fermentation?
A: The pH of the kombucha tea decreases with fermentation time. Bacteria and yeasts metabolize sucrose into organic acids such as acetic acid and glucuronic acid, which decreases the pH from 5 to 3 within 12 days of fermentation.

Q: What is the significance of theaflavin and thearubigins in black tea?
A: Theaflavin and thearubigins are polyphenolic derivatives present in black tea. They contribute to the flavor and aroma of black tea and are also believed to have potential health benefits.

Q: How does the protein content change during kombucha fermentation?
A: The protein content increases rapidly with fermentation time, reaching a peak at 12 days and then decreasing thereafter. These proteins are likely extra cellular proteins secreted by bacteria and yeasts during the fermentation process.

Q: How does the total count of bacteria and yeast change during kombucha fermentation?
A: The total count of bacteria and yeast increases rapidly until the 9th day of fermentation and then decreases. The decrease in microbial content after 9 days is likely due to acid shock (low pH), which influences the multiplication of bacteria and yeast.

Q: How do the concentrations of epicatechin isomers change during kombucha fermentation?
A: All catechins studied were degraded up to the 9th day of kombucha fermentation and showed a marked increase on the 12th day. It is assumed that the increased concentration of epicatechin isomers observed on the 12th day is due to the release of catechins from acid-sensitive microbial cells.

Q: How does the stability of tea polyphenols vary during kombucha fermentation?
A: This study focused on the changes in content of organic acids, epicatechin isomers, theaflavin and thearubigins in kombucha tea prepared from green tea, black tea and tea manufacture waste during tea fungus fermentation. The study found that tea polyphenols, particularly theaflavin and thearubigins, were relatively stable during kombucha fermentation.

Q: What role do dietary phenolic antioxidants play in relation to diseases?
A: Dietary phenolic antioxidants help to prevent oxidative damage to cell membranes and DNA, which can lead to cancerous mutations. They also inhibit redox-responsive pro-inflammatory transcription factors, which are implicated in promoting chronic inflammatory diseases and cancer.

Q: What is the importance of total phenolic content (TPC) and total anthocyanin content (TAC) in these fruits?
A: The TPC and TAC of these fruits help to determine their overall nutritional value and potential health benefits. High TPC and TAC values indicate that the fruits are rich in antioxidants and anti-inflammatories.

Q: What were the findings regarding the most abundant compounds among those quantified in the fruits?
A: The anthocyanins were found to be the most abundant compounds among those quantified.

Q: What was surprising about the antiradical activity of some of the fruits?
A: It was surprising that despite having high levels of delphinidin 3-glucoside, a potent antiradical compound, the fruit of Syzygium cumini showed only very average antiradical activity.

Q: What role do ellagic acids and their derivatives play in the Myrtaceae fruits?
A: Ellagic acids and their derivatives are likely to contribute significantly to the overall total phenolic content (TPC) and antiradical activity in these fruits.

Q: What were the findings regarding quercetin, quercitrin, and rutin in the studied fruits?
A: Quercetin, its glycosides quercitrin and rutin were found to be prevalent in the 14 studied fruits. They are important dietary constituents with many chemopreventive activities.

Q: How can the consumption of fruits from the Myrtaceae family contribute to health?
A: Given that cancers and heart disease are the leading causes of death in the United States, studies indicate that diets high in naturally occurring antioxidants and anti-inflammatories are important as a first-line strategy of chemoprevention. The Myrtaceae fruits, being a rich source of biologically active phenolic compounds, can contribute to this dietary strategy.

Q: What are the advantages of hydrogels as wound dressings?
A: Hydrogels are excellent for wound dressing due to their ability to absorb excess wound exudates, protect the wound from secondary infection, and effectively promote the healing process by providing a moisturized wound healing environment. They can also be removed without causing trauma to the wound.

Q: What is the main disadvantage of hydrogels prepared by irradiation?
A: The main drawback of hydrogels prepared by irradiation is their poor mechanical strength.

Q: What properties were evaluated in the experiment?
A: The properties evaluated include the gel fraction, the swelling behavior, the water evaporation rate, the rheological properties, and the antibacterial behavior, and their relationship to ws-chitosan content.

Q: How do the hydrogels made by combined irradiation and freeze-thawing differ from those prepared by irradiation or freeze-thawing alone?
A: Hydrogels made by combined irradiation and freeze-thawing show similar morphology with smaller pores, possess good mechanical strength, have adequate water evaporation rate and translucent appearance. They also have improved thermal stability, and the gel fraction and storage modulus decrease while the swelling capacity increases with increasing ws-chitosan content.

Q: How does the addition of ws-chitosan affect the properties of PVA hydrogels?
A: The addition of ws-chitosan simplifies the process of making hydrogels as it dissolves in acid solution. Hydrogels with more ws-chitosan show a larger pH dependence and swelling capacity while pure PVA hydrogel does not show pH sensitivity and has the smallest swelling capacity.

Q: How does the swelling capacity of the hydrogels change with cross-linking density?
A: The swelling capacity of hydrogels can be affected by many factors, such as the cross-linking density, the hydratability of the materials, the ionic strength and pH value of the media, as well as the temperature of the environment. The larger the cross-linking density, the lower the swelling capacity.

Q: How does the water evaporation rate from the hydrogels change over time?
A: The water evaporation from hydrogels prepared by freeze-thawing alone and by freeze-thawing followed by irradiation proceeds rapidly compared to those prepared by the other methods. The water evaporation rate slows down in later stages.

Q: How does the mechanical strength of the hydrogels change with the irradiation and freeze-thawing processing?
A: Hydrogels made by irradiation followed by freeze-thawing have an even larger mechanical strength compared to those prepared by pure freeze-thawing and freeze-thawing followed by irradiation.

Q: How does the temperature affect the storage modulus of the hydrogels?
A: The storage modulus of hydrogels made by irradiation alone exhibits almost no temperature dependence due to the stable chemical cross-linking structure. The storage modulus of hydrogels made by pure freeze-thawing reduces significantly when the temperature is going above 50 °C due to the breakdown of the physical networks. The thermal stability of hydrogels made by combined irradiation and freeze-thawing, especially for hydrogels made by irradiation followed by freeze-thawing, is greatly improved compared to that made by pure freeze-thawing.

Q: What was the main conclusion of the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments (CAAAs) regarding the presence of mercury in stack emissions from fossil fuel-fired electric utility power plants?
A: The CAAAs required the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to determine whether the presence of mercury in the stack emissions from fossil fuel-fired electric utility power plants poses an unacceptable public health risk. The reports presented to Congress indicated that EPA views mercury as a potential threat to human health, suggesting that mercury controls at some point may be necessary.

Q: Why is the accurate measurement of mercury emissions important?
A: Reliable mercury emission and ambient measurement methods are useful for a variety of reasons including estimating the anthropogenic flux of mercury to the environment, identifying atmospheric transport and transformation processes, determining background and natural mercury concentrations, assessing deposition and methylation mechanisms in ecosystems, and evaluating human health risks, among others.

Q: How does fly ash affect the mercury speciation?
A: The study found that fly ash is important in determining mercury speciation in the flue gas streams. It was found that 10–20% of the injected Hg0 was measured as Hg2+ as it passed through the bed of ash.

Q: What role does the Ontario Hydro method play in mercury speciation analysis?
A: The Ontario Hydro method is a modification of EPA Method 29, and it was found to be a promising method for determining mercury speciation in a full-scale test program at a midwestern power plant.

Q: What were the findings regarding the effect of Cl2 on mercury speciation?
A: The study found that Cl2 has a significant impact on mercury speciation when the Ontario Hydro method is used. However, the effect of Cl2 may be a result of aqueous phase reactions in the impinger solutions.

Q: What were the findings regarding the interaction between NOx and fly ash?
A: The study found that there is a significant interaction between NOx and fly ash. The concentration of the added Hg0 measured as Hg2+ is significantly high when these gases are part of the simulated flue gas and passed through the fly ash.

Q: How does SO2 affect mercury speciation?
A: The study found that the addition of SO2 completely eliminates the effect of the Cl2 on mercury speciation if fly ash is not present. Otherwise, the effect of SO2 decreases the impact of Cl2 on mercury speciation.

Q: How does thermal processing affect the antioxidant capacities of phenolic additives?
A: The paper reports that thermal processing can enhance the total antioxidant activities of some foods like tomatoes and carrots, while lowering the antioxidant capacities of others like soybeans. Therefore, it is possible that thermal processing could affect the antioxidant capacity of grape seed extract (GSE).

Q: How was the antioxidant activity of the GSE-fortified bread determined?
A: The antioxidant activities of the GSE-fortified bread were determined using the trolox equivalent antioxidant capacity (TEAC) assay.

Q: How does the addition of GSE affect the color of bread?
A: The paper reports that GSE can change the color of bread, making it more vibrant. Specifically, it decreases L ∗ values (whiteness) while increasing a ∗ and b ∗ values (red and blue colors respectively).

Q: Did the sensory evaluation reveal any negative effects of GSE addition?
A: The sensory evaluation revealed no significant alterations in the quality attributes of bread, such as sweetness, porosity, astringency and stickiness, for breads added with different levels of GSE.

Q: How does GSE addition affect the formation of CML in bread?
A: The study found that addition of GSE dose-dependently reduced CML content in bread crust relative to the control. Specifically, adding 600 and 1000 mg of GSE to bread (500 g) led to over 30% and 50% reduction in bread crust CML content, respectively.

Q: How does the antioxidant activity of cell-free systems (e.g. in bread) get affected by thermal processing?
A: The data suggests that thermal processing exerts a significant effect on the antioxidant activity of cell-free systems. However, whether similar effects will be observed in humans remains unknown.

Q: What are some properties of plants of the Apiaceae family?
A: The Apiaceae family possesses a range of compounds with many biological activities. Some of the main properties are ability to induce apoptosis, antibacterial, hepatoprotective and vaso-relaxant activities, cyclooxygenase inhibitory effect and antitumor action.

Q: What is the significance of black zira (Zireh e Irani, Zireh koohi or Bunium persicum [Boiss.] Fedtsch) in traditional medicine and food flavouring?
A: Black zira is an important aromatic perennial plant that originates in an area from central Asia to North India. It is consumed widely as a condiment and as a traditional flavouring in a number of ethnic cuisines and food industries. It is also used in folk medicine for treating diarrhoea and dyspepsia.

Q: What role does cumin (Cuminum cyminum L.) play in the food industry and traditional medicine?
A: Cumin is a monotypic genus in the family Apiaceae. It is an annual herb and is one of the most important and widely consumed condiments. It is also an ingredient in Ayurvedic medicine for curing stomach ailments, diarrhoea and dysentery.

Q: What are the findings regarding the antibacterial activities of essential oils from the three Apiaceae species tested?
A: The study found that plants of the Apiaceae family, particularly the essential oil of Carum copticum (Zenyan in Persian) had the strongest antibacterial activity against tested food-borne bacteria.

Q: How were the components of the EO samples identified?
A: The components of the EO samples were identified by GC and GC–MS analyses. The GC–MS apparatus was used to separate and identify the oil components based on their retention indices (RI) obtained with reference to the n-alkane series.

Q: How did the FICIndex of the EOs reveal the synergistic and additive effects of combinations of antibacterial effects of B. persicum and Cu. cyminum EOs?
A: The FICIndex of the EOs was calculated by summing the separate fractional inhibitory concentrations (FICs) of each EO. A FICIndex of 0.9 or less indicated synergistic activities, 0.9 < FICIndex < 1.1 additive effects, and FICIndex > 1.1 antagonistic effects. The combination of B. persicum and Cu. cyminum EOs had higher inhibitory activity against most pathogenic bacteria, compared to use of each EO alone, indicating synergistic effects.

Q: Why are tannins of interest as corrosion inhibitors?
A: Tannins are non-expensive and ecologically acceptable corrosion inhibitors. They are complex mixtures extracted from plant material that are either being investigated or are already in use as corrosion inhibitors in aqueous media.

Q: What are the significant characteristics of tannins that influence their inhibitory action?
A: Tannins have the ability to form chelate compounds with ferrous and ferric ions that are released in the course of steel corrosion process. Therefore, the ferric tannate formation influences the inhibitory mechanism of tannins.

Q: What is the impact of pH on the inhibitory action of mimosa tannin?
A: At pH <3, mimosa tannin acts as a corrosion inhibitor on bare steel in acidic solutions. At pH ≥3, ferric tannate is formed, and inhibition is probably due to the physisorption of ferric tannate on the steel surface, which inhibits the corrosion reaction.

Q: How does the apparent activation energy of the dissolution process change with inhibitor concentration?
A: The increase in the apparent activation energy at low inhibitor concentrations, at pH=1, may be interpreted as physical adsorption that occurs in the first stage. A drop in E a°, with respect to the uninhibited solution, observed at the highest inhibitor concentration indicates chemisorption.

Q: What are the five stable phases of copper sulphide (CuxS) at room temperature?
A: The five stable phases of copper sulphide (CuxS) at room temperature are covellite (CuS), anilite (Cu1.75S), digenite (Cu1.8S), djurleite (Cu1.95S), and chalcocite (Cu2S).

Q: How are CuxS thin films utilized in solar applications?
A: CuxS thin films have been found to possess near ideal solar control characteristics and are efficiently used in solid junction solar cells which have many applications.

Q: What are the properties of CuxS thin films deposited by the chemical method?
A: The CuxS thin films deposited by the chemical method are uniform, well adherent to the substrates, and have a nanocrystalline structure. They have a direct band gap of 2.35 eV and show p-type electrical conductivity.

Q: What are the techniques used to characterize the structural, surface morphological, compositional, optical and electrical properties of CuxS thin films?
A: The techniques used for the characterization include X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), Rutherford back scattering (RBS), optical absorbance/transmittance, and electrical resistivity measurements.

Q: How is the modified chemical method for deposition of CuxS films expected to work?
A: The modified chemical method for deposition of CuxS films involves immersion of the substrate into separate cation and anion precursor solutions and rinsing between every immersion with ion exchange water to avoid homogeneous precipitation.

Q: What are the results of the XRD analysis of the Cu2S films?
A: The XRD analysis found that the formed compound is Cu2S with a hexagonal crystal structure.

Q: What are the findings related to the optical properties of the Cu2S thin films?
A: The Cu2S thin films have a high absorbance of 104 cm−1 and a maximum percentage transmission of 53.4% at a wavelength of 630 nm. The film's optical bandgap energy is found to be 2.35 eV.

Q: How is the electrical resistivity of the Cu2S films determined and what is its value?
A: The electrical resistivity of the Cu2S films is determined using the dc two point probe method in the temperature range 300–500 K. The type of electrical conductivity of the films was determined by the polarity of thermally generated voltage at the hot end of the film.

Q: How do the Cu2S films exhibit semiconducting behavior?
A: The room temperature resistivity of Cu2S thin film was found to be of the order of 10−2 Ω cm, indicating a semiconducting behavior. The resistivity decreases with an increase in temperature.

Q: What is the field of study that deals with the use of light in biology and medicine?
A: The field of study that deals with the use of light in biology and medicine is called Biophotonics.

Q: What is the role of a Surface plasmon resonance interferometer (SPRi)?
A: A Surface plasmon resonance interferometer (SPRi) is an instrument used for sensing and analyzing molecular interactions. It works by stimulating surface plasmons on a metallic substrate, and observing the shifts in the resonance wavelength due to changes in the refractive index of the substrate.

Q: What is the concept of "Surface-enhanced Raman scattering" (SERS)?
A: Surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) is a phenomenon where molecules interact stronger with certain substrates, like metallic nanoparticles, than with others. This interaction can lead to a dramatic increase in the scattering of Raman light, providing a sensitive method for molecular analysis.

Q: What is the concept of "Optical negative-index metamaterials"?
A: Optical negative-index metamaterials are substances that have a negative index of refraction, which means they can bend light in a way that is opposite to that of traditional materials. This capability could enable a range of optical applications, including negative refraction.

Q: What are some potential biomedical applications of plasmon resonant metal nanoparticles?
A: Plasmon resonant metal nanoparticles have been studied for their potential use in biomedical applications. This includes their use as sensors for the detection of analytes in serum or other biological fluids, and their ability to enhance the sensitivity of surrounding tissues to near-infrared light.

Q: How significantly do impurities affect the electrical and optical properties of semiconductor materials?
A: Impurities induce substantial modifications in the electrical and optical properties of semiconductor materials. As pure material, stoichiometric TiO2 can absorb a small percentage of the sunlight. But by doping with different impurities like In, Cr, Cd, the structural properties of TiO2 thin films can be modified, consequently changing its optical constants and absorption spectra.

Q: What is the influence of the substrate nature on the structure of TiO2 thin films?
A: The substrate nature influences the structure of TiO2 thin films. This is connected with the mobility of the adatoms on the substrate surface, which is responsible for the degree and type of nucleation on the substrate. For instance, when deposited onto ITO substrates, the TiO2 thin films tend to have a more porous surface compared to those deposited onto glass substrates.

Q: How is the transmittance of TiO2 thin films affected by doping?
A: The transmittance of TiO2 thin films is increased by doping them with cerium, niobium, or iron. This is due to the pure anatase structures of the doped films, which have lower density and refractive index, leading to higher transmittances.

Q: What is the effect of doping on the optical band gap of TiO2 thin films?
A: Doping influences the optical band gap of TiO2 thin films. For instance, when doped with cerium or niobium, the weight percentage of the anatase phase increases, leading to a higher optical band gap. However, iron doping decreases the optical band gap due to the increasing weight percentage of the rutile phase.

Q: What is the role of reactive sputtering in obtaining TiO2 thin films?
A: Reactive sputtering is one of the most utilized methods for obtaining uniform and dense TiO2 thin films with well-controlled stoichiometry. A r.f. (13.56 MHz) sputtering technique from a metallic titanium target of 99.5% purity and 60 mm diameter was used in this study.

Q: How were the weights of the anatase and rutile phases determined in the TiO2 thin films?
A: The weight percentage of the anatase and rutile phases in the TiO2 thin films were determined using the equation  WA=11+1.265IR/IA where I A denotes the intensity of strongest anatase reflection and I R is the intensity of strongest rutile reflection.

Q: How does the nature of the substrate affect the surface morphology of TiO2 thin films?
A: The substrate nature influences the surface morphology of TiO2 thin films. For instance, films deposited onto ITO substrates exhibit a porous surface, while those deposited onto glass substrates have a more compact one.

Q: How is the transmittance of the TiO2 thin film influenced by its structure?
A: The transmittance of the TiO2 thin film is influenced by its structure. For instance, doped TiO2 films with a single anatase phase exhibit lower n values, and higher transmittances compared to the pure TiO2 film.

Q: What unique properties make reactive sputtered titanium oxide and nitride thin films attractive for study?
A: Reactive sputtered titanium oxide and nitride thin films are of interest because of their remarkable optical and electronic properties, mechanical behaviors, and chemical stability. They also have interesting physical properties that could be utilized in solar collector devices.

Q: What is the significance of the target potential in the reactive sputtering process?
A: The target potential in the reactive sputtering process is indicative of the state of the surface of the target and characterizes the kinetics of poisoning by the reactive gas. It can be used to monitor instabilities of the reactive sputtering process.

Q: How does the oxygen pulsing technique affect the final properties of the films?
A: The oxygen pulsing technique allows for the periodic substitution of the nitride layer by an oxide layer at the surface of the target, which can lead to the growth of films containing mixed solid phases by competition between TiO and TiN at the surface of depositing films.

Q: How is the chemical composition of the films determined?
A: The chemical composition of the films was determined by electron probe microanalysis (EPMA) with the wavelength dispersion method.

Q: What are the potential applications of electrochromic materials?
A: Electrochromic materials are attracting interest for use in energy efficient "smart windows", glare-free and variable reflectance mirrors, high-contrast non-emissive information displays, switchable displays, devices for thermal control, semiconductor-based sensors, etc.

Q: What is the mechanism of the electrochromism in nickel oxide material?
A: The phenomenon of anodic electrochromism in nickel oxide allows its potential application as a counter electrode in electrochromic devices. The mechanism is based on the redox process Ni3+↔Ni2+.

Q: How is the annealing process influenced on the film structure?
A: The annealing process influences the film structure, increasing the degree of crystallinity of the deposited material. X-ray diffractometry and infrared spectra were used to confirm this.

Q: How are the as-deposited and post-deposition treated NiO thin films electrically?
A: The as-deposited thin films are dielectric, while the post-deposition treated ones are characterized by resistivity of several MΩs/cm2 at room temperature.

Q: What is the implication of the presence of intercalated –NCO species in the as-deposited films?
A: The presence of intercalated anions within the nickel oxide films may be crucial for their electrochromic properties.

Q: How is the optical absorption of NiO thin films affected by annealing?
A: The absorption coefficient of the annealed NiO thin films increases upon annealing, indicating structural variations. The absorption spectra of post-deposition treated films with different thicknesses were presented, showing that the absorption gradually decreases with an increase in wavelength.

Q: What is the usefulness of chemical vapor deposition (CVD) in the semiconductor industry?
A: Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) is widely used in the semiconductor industry because it provides thin films with a high uniformity in chemical composition. It also offers the ability to cover any geometric shape with a deposit of crystalline nanoparticles. Another advantage of CVD over other methods is the ability to selectively deposit films onto a specific substrate area.

Q: What precursor has been used in the experiments to generate metallic coatings and oxide films by CVD techniques?
A: The precursor used in the experiments to generate metallic coatings and oxide films by CVD techniques is 2,4-Pentanedionate copper(II), Cu(acac)2, due to its reasonable volatility, low decomposition temperature, good stability in air, low-toxicity, and its commercial availability.

Q: How does the deposition temperature influence the nature of the deposited films?
A: The deposition temperature significantly influences the nature of the deposited films. For instance, a deposition temperature above 315°C was high enough to obtain a continuous film of crystalline copper oxides over the fiberglass.

Q: What method was used to examine the film growth experiments?
A: The film growth experiments were carried out using a horizontal-flow, atmospheric-pressure CVD reactor.

Q: How were the copper films on the fiberglass examined?
A: The copper films on the fiberglass were examined using several techniques such as X-ray diffraction patterns, a scanning electron microscope, and a UV–VIS spectrophotometer.

Q: What was the result of the adhesion test for the copper oxide films on the fiberglass?
A: The adhesion of the copper oxide films to the fiberglass was good. The film coating did not exhibit any peeling after washing with warm ethanol, therefore, the covered fiberglass passed the adhesion test.

Q: What effect does the nature of the copper oxide mixture have on the catalytic activity?
A: The nature of the copper oxide mixture has a significant effect on the catalytic activity. When the film on the fiberglass is conformed by a type of copper oxide, the catalytic activity for the ethanol oxidation is low. However, if an oxide mixture exists in the deposited film, the catalytic activity increases drastically.

Q: What was the role of the deposition of Cu before oxidizing in the experiment?
A: The deposition of Cu before oxidizing plays an important role as it is a catalytic specie that facilitates the decomposition of the organic group at relatively low-temperatures.

Q: How were the crystallite sizes of the deposited copper oxide phases determined?
A: The crystallite sizes of the deposited copper oxide phases were determined using X-ray diffraction patterns. The mean crystallite size in the [hkl] direction was obtained from the corresponding peak broadening with the Debye-Scherrer equation.

Q: What were the conclusions about the potential use of fiberglass impregnated with copper oxides as a catalyst for the oxidation of ethanol?
A: The paper concluded that fiberglass impregnated with copper oxides has shown remarkable properties for the oxidation of ethanol. Therefore, these materials could be potential catalysts for the conversion of organic contaminants present into an air stream.

Q: What are the potential applications of ITM technology?
A: ITMs are fabricated from ionic and mixed-conducting ceramic oxides and can be used in various applications. This includes the separation of oxygen from air, and the conversion of natural gas to syngas, which can be further processed into liquid fuels. The technology also has potential in the chemical industry for co-generation of electricity.

Q: What are the challenges that need to be overcome for the successful commercialization of ITM technology?
A: Some of the technical challenges include designing and engineering processes that can integrate the capabilities of an ITM, developing stable ITM materials and seals with required performance characteristics, and developing economic ceramic membrane fabrication technology. The long-term reliability of these membranes, measured in years, is also a challenge.

Q: What is the significance of the SEOS™ Oxygen Generator developed by Air Products and Ceramatec?
A: The SEOS™ Oxygen Generator is a stand-alone electrochemical device developed by Air Products and Ceramatec for separating oxygen from air. It uses a multiple planar cell stack and unique design features such as a flat-plate multi-cell stack, high conductivity ceria-based electrolyte composition, and thermo-mechanical compatible perovskite interconnects.

Q: What is the potential benefit of integrating ITM Oxygen technology with gas turbine engines?
A: The integration of ITM Oxygen technology with gas turbine engines can significantly improve the overall efficiency of the system, resulting in better environmental performance and lower costs. It also makes the technology more capital-intensive but appropriately so for larger supplies of oxygen, such as tonnage quantities.

Q: What is the role of ITM Syngas in the gas-to-liquids (GTL) process?
A: The ITM Syngas process is a technology being developed by Air Products and its partners for the production of syngas, a combination of hydrogen and carbon monoxide, which is a major intermediate for the production of both hydrogen and gas-derived liquid products. The process combines the functions of air separation and autothermal reforming into a single step.

Q: What are the key requirements for the membrane material in the ITM Syngas process?
A: The membrane material in the ITM Syngas process must show long-term stability in reducing and oxidizing atmospheres, and must be compatible with the reduction and reforming catalysts. It also has to exhibit a low chemical expansion effect to enhance operational lifetime.

Q: What is the phased development program for the ITM Syngas process?
A: The ITM Syngas process is being developed through a planned, phased development program that includes a bench scale test, a sub-scale engineering prototype, a pre-commercial technology demonstration unit, and a commercial-scale world-scale GTL application.

Q: What is the significance of the United States Department of Energy's involvement in the development of ITM technologies?
A: The United States Department of Energy (DOE) is a key participant in the development of ITM technologies. The DOE has a strong interest in remote natural gas conversion and has funded a significant amount of research and development in this area. The DOE is also closely involved in the integrated gas-to-liquids (GTL) process, making it a critical player in the advancement of ITM technology.

Q: What are the two different commercialisation strategies for SOFC stacks?
A: One approach is to design a SOFC system operating in excess of about 850°C that can be combined with a gas turbine to provide a power plant with a total electrical efficiency around 70%. It is envisaged that such units will be marketed in the MW size. The other strategy is to lower the temperature as far as possible without compromising the electrode kinetics and internal resistance of the cell, which could allow for smaller-scale CHP applications.

Q: What is the role of Ce0.9Gd0.1O1.95 composition in SOFC technology?
A: The Ce0.9Gd0.1O1.95 composition has been found to be suitable for IT-SOFC technology, particularly for 500°C operation. It has a wider ionic domain at 500°C than other compositions, and its activation energy is relatively low, which makes it suitable for small polaron activated hopping process.

Q: What is the influence of grain boundary impurities on ceramic electrolytes?
A: The deleterious effects of impurity grain boundary phases on the performance of ceramic electrolytes have been known for many decades. The presence of grain boundary impurities, such as SiO2, can decrease the ionic conductivity and increase the activation energy, which can negatively impact the performance of the electrolyte.

Q: How does the oxygen-reduction reaction at a porous mixed conducting oxide electrode occur?
A: The predominant cathode polarisation voltage of the oxygen-reduction reaction is associated with heterogeneous chemical reactions within the electrode. The actual charge transfer step across the electrode–electrolyte interface is relatively facile and only makes a minor contribution to the overall cathode over-potential.

Q: Why is it important to keep the electrolyte SiO2 content as low as possible?
A: Siliceous impurities can segregate to electrode–electrolyte three-phase boundary regions and dramatically increase the effective electrode resistance. Therefore, it is important to fabricate CeO2 electrolytes with low SiO2 contents for technological applications.

Q: What is the role of activated hopping process in the transport of 4f electrons in the rare-earth oxides?
A: The activated hopping process implies relatively low mobilities and activation energies, and it is used to interpret the transport of 4f electrons in the rare-earth oxides.

Q: How do the authors propose implementing composite cathodes to improve the effective oxygen diffusion at 500°C?
A: The authors suggest using composite cathodes comprising LSCF/CGO(10) to improve the effective oxygen diffusion. As soon as the volume fraction of CGO(10) reaches the percolation threshold, the cathode ASR is significantly reduced, making this an effective solution.

Q: What role does oxygen vacancies play in the surface chemistry of CeO2(1 1 1)?
A: Oxygen vacancies are a significant feature of the surface chemistry of CeO2(1 1 1). They are the result of reduction and can serve as active sites for various chemical reactions, including the oxidation of Ce3+ sites.

Q: What is the impact of vacuum annealing on the CeO2(1 1 1) surface?
A: Vacuum annealing (treatment in vacuum conditions) results in significant levels of surface reduction on the CeO2(1 1 1) surface. It also increases the amount of oxygen vacancies, which can serve as active sites for chemical reactions.

Q: How does the reactivity of Ce3+ sites on non-(1 1 1) terminations affect the oxidative behavior of water on reduced powders and films?
A: The reactivity of Ce3+ sites on non-(1 1 1) terminations accounts for the observed oxidative behavior of water on reduced powders and films. This means that the ability of water to oxidize these sites varies depending on the specific surface termination it encounters.

Q: What is the role of oxygen defects in the surface chemistry of ceria?
A: Oxygen defects, in the form of oxygen vacancies and oxygen atoms, are a significant feature of the surface chemistry of ceria. They are the result of reduction and can serve as active sites for various chemical reactions, including the oxidation of Ce3+ sites.

Q: How is the level of reduction on the CeO2(1 1 1) surface affected by water treatment?
A: Water treatment, either by exposure to water at a high temperature or by exposure to water vapor, can further reduce the surface of CeO2(1 1 1), even after accounting for the initial reduction. It also increases the level of Ce3+ related features in the XPS spectra.

Q: How does the surface termination of ceria affect its reactivity towards water?
A: The reactivity of Ce3+ sites on the surface of ceria towards water likely depends on the surface termination and morphology. While some surfaces, such as atomically flat surfaces, may be unable to oxidize Ce3+ sites, reduced surfaces and surfaces with certain morphologies have been observed to support oxidation and reduction reactions of the same molecule on different parts of the particle.

Q: What is the "law of corresponding states" that was observed in the experiments on diffusion?
A: The "law of corresponding states" that was observed in the experiments on diffusion suggests that, although the specific activation energies and other properties may vary, the behavior of adatoms will display consistent patterns once the energy and distance scales of the respective potentials are reduced.

Q: How was the Lennard-Jones potential used in the studies?
A: The Lennard-Jones potential was used as a model for the potential energy function in the simulations. It was assumed that this potential contained no adjustable parameters.

Q: What is the role of the dividing surface in the calculation of jump rates?
A: The dividing surface, defined in terms of the coordinates of the adatom, is crucial in determining the jump rates. The location of the transition states is usually found very close to the binding sites, and the dividing surface is chosen as the transition state in the calculation.

Q: How does the variation of the pre-factor with different surfaces of a metal contribute to our understanding of the patterns in the properties?
A: The variation of the pre-factor with different surfaces of a metal can provide insight into the activation energy for self-diffusion. If the pre-factor for a given surface is assumed rather than measured, a rule for estimating it would be useful in determining the activation energy in cases where limited experimental data is available.

Q: What are the main components of the Arrhenius parameters for diffusive hopping on the surfaces of FCC metals?
A: The Arrhenius parameters for diffusive hopping on the surfaces of FCC metals include the activation energy (E a) and the pre-exponential factor (D 0). These parameters are typically calculated using Monte Carlo variational transition state theory (MCVTST) with dynamical recrossing correction factors.

Q: How is the dividing surface evaluated in the MCVTST calculations?
A: In MCVTST calculations, the dividing surface is evaluated variationally to give the minimum flux for the jump from an initial adsorption site to a reactant space. The dynamical correction factor (F) is computed by integrating a few trajectories using initial conditions selected from the phase points on the dividing surface to determine if they lead to recrossing of the dividing surface before reaching the product state or do not lead to the reactant space.

Q: What are some of the key findings regarding the ratio of the cohesive energy to the activation energy on FCC metals?
A: The study found that the ratio of the cohesive energy to the activation energy, denoted as R, is constant within statistical error for L-J potentials, suggesting that for given Miller indices of the surface and channel, R does not change with the substance.

Q: How do the activation energies and pre-exponential factors vary among different surfaces?
A: The study found that the smallest value of the pre-exponential factor (D 0) is for the (1 1 1) system, followed by values for diffusion on the (1 0 0) surface. The next largest value of D 0 corresponds to diffusion on the (1 1 0) surface in the [110] direction, and the largest value corresponds to diffusion on the (1 1 0) surface in the [0 0 1] direction.

Q: How can the knowledge of the ratio of the cohesive energy to the activation energy (R) be useful in determining the activation energy?
A: The knowledge of the ratio of the cohesive energy to the activation energy (R) can be useful in extracting the activation energy from limited experimental data and the Arrhenius equation. If R is much higher than the values predicted by the L-J potential or by the ab initio potential, a possible explanation for the discrepancy may be that the diffusion occurs via the exchange mechanism.

Q: What properties make sulfide-based lithium ion conductors promising for novel solid-state lithium-ion battery systems?
A: Sulfide-based lithium ion conductors are promising for solid electrolytes in novel solid-state lithium-ion battery systems due to their high conductivities, single ion-conductive properties, and nonflammability. Glasses such as Li2S–SiS2 and Li2S–P2S5 have shown high conductivities at room temperature. The conductivities of these glasses can be enhanced by the precipitation of metastable phases from the pristine glasses.

Q: How were the extremely high conductivities of over 10− 3 S cm− 1 at room temperature achieved?
A: The extremely high conductivities of over 10− 3 S cm− 1 at room temperature were achieved by crystallization of the Li2S–P2S5 glasses. Usually, crystallization of glasses results in lowering conductivities because crystals with low conductivities are precipitated. However, in this case, the crystallization process enhanced the conductivity by precipitating metastable phases.

Q: What is the role of Li2S in the Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramic electrolytes?
A: Li2S serves as a lithium source and is necessary for the preparation of Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramic electrolytes. The conductivities of the glasses and glass-ceramics increase with an increase in the Li2S content.

Q: How were the crystalline phases of the Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramics identified?
A: The crystalline phases of the Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramics were identified through X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman measurements.

Q: What is the significance of the new crystalline phase discovered in the Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramics?
A: The discovery of a new crystalline phase in the Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramics is significant as it exhibits high conductivity and is a key to enhancing the conductivity of the Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramics.

Q: What role do P2S7 4− and PS4 3− ions play in enhancing the conductivities of materials based on the Li2S–P2S5 system?
A: P2S7 4− and PS4 3− ions are found to be very important to enhance the conductivities of materials based on the Li2S–P2S5 system. They were observed to be the main ions in the highly conductive thio-LISICON analogs.

Q: How do the conductivities and activation energies of the Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramics change with heat treatment?
A: The conductivities of the Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramics increase with increasing heat treatment temperatures. The highest conductivity of 3.2 × 10− 3 S cm− 1 was observed after heating at 360 °C. The activation energies for conduction were also calculated from a slope of the conductivities, and they decreased and then increased with increasing heat treatment temperatures.

Q: How are the superionic metastable phases significant in developing high lithium ion conducting Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramics?
A: The formation of superionic metastable phases is considered a vital factor in developing high lithium ion conducting Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramics. These phases, which are obtained by crystallization of the mother glasses, can lead to remarkable enhancement of conducting properties.

Q: What was the key to achieving a glass-ceramic with the highest conductivity of 3.2 × 10− 3 S cm− 1 at room temperature?
A: The key to achieving a glass-ceramic with the highest conductivity of 3.2 × 10− 3 S cm− 1 at room temperature was the formation of the new crystal and the thio-LISICON II analog. These metastable phases, obtained by crystallization of the mother glasses, enhanced the conductivity of the glass-ceramic.

Q: How do the local structure of the glass-ceramics and the compositions influence the conducting properties of Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramics?
A: From viewpoints of local structure of the glass-ceramics, it was found that structural units suitable for fast lithium ion conductors in the system Li2S–P2S5 were pyro-thiophosphate (P2S7 4−) and ortho-thiophosphate (PS4 3−). The conducting properties of Li2S–P2S5 glass-ceramics largely depended on the precipitated crystalline phases, which were controlled by the compositions and heat treatment conditions of the mother glasses.

Q: What is nickel cobaltite and why is it useful?
A: Nickel cobaltite, also known as NiCo2O4, is a mixed-metal oxide spinel that has shown exceptional ability to serve as an oxygen evolution electrode. It also possesses interesting magnetic properties, being ferrimagnetic with a Curie temperature of approximately 400°C.

Q: What are the surface compositions of NiCo2O4 prepared by the thermal decomposition and sol–gel methods?
A: The thermal decomposition method yields NiCo2O4 with a surface that is slightly oxygen-deficient. The sol–gel method, on the other hand, produces surfaces with bulk-like compositions that are more stoichiometric.

Q: How were the surface concentrations of oxygen and other elements determined?
A: The surface concentrations of oxygen and other elements were determined using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Auger electron spectroscopy (AES).

Q: What is the impact of surface hydroxylation on NiCo2O4 surface analysis?
A: The presence of surface hydroxylation can affect the analysis, as it can modify the bonding energies and peak shapes of the nickel and cobalt 2p core level photoemission features. It is also difficult to separate the hydroxylation from other surface oxide features, such as oxyhydroxide formation, using XPS data.

Q: What role does phase separation play in the properties of NiCo2O4?
A: Phase separation, arising from the decomposition of the surface layers of NiCo2O4, can lead to the formation of monoxide-like surface oxides. This has significant implications for the reactivity and behavior of NiCo2O4 in electrocatalytic processes.

Q: What technological importance do lithium ionic conductors hold?
A: Lithium ionic conductors are technologically important as they could potentially solve the safety problems of the rechargeable lithium ion battery using non-aqueous liquid electrolytes. They are also of interest for future applications as solid electrolytes for all-solid lithium batteries.

Q: What is the main advantage of using ceramic crystalline materials in the construction of ionic conductors?
A: One main advantage of using ceramic crystalline materials is their stability at high temperatures. Additionally, if their crystal structure is designed for high ionic conduction, they might have higher conductivity than the corresponding glasses.

Q: What were the key synthetic steps?
A:
The key synthetic steps were

1. Weighing the starting materials
2. Mixing them in appropriate molar ratios in an argon-filled glove box
3. Putting the mixture into a carbon-coated quartz tube
4. Heating the tube at a reaction temperature of 600–800°C for 8 hours
5. Cooling the tube slowly to room temperature after the reaction.

Q: How were the properties of the synthesized materials analyzed?
A: The properties of the synthesized materials were analyzed using X-ray diffraction patterns, AC impedance methods, and cyclic voltammetry.

Q: What were the key findings regarding the conductivity of the new thio-LISICON materials?
A: The thio-LISICON materials synthesized in the study had higher ionic conductivities than the oxide LISICON and Li3PO4–Li4SiO4 solid solutions. The highest conductivity was observed for the sample with a composition of Li4+x+δ(Ge1−δ′−xGax)S4, with a conductivity of 6.5×10−5 S cm−1 at room temperature.

Q: Can you explain the experimental procedure for measuring the conductivity?
A: The conductivity was measured using AC impedance methods. A gold paste was painted onto both sides of the samples and then treated in an evacuated quartz tube at 350°C for 5 hours. The measurements were carried out for the sample with a pellet (8 mm diameter and 2–3 mm thick) between room temperature and 300°C in a nitrogen gas flow.

Q: What was the chemical stability of the thio-LISICON material tested for?
A: The chemical stability of the thio-LISICON was examined by the contact of lithium metal with the cold-pressed Li4+x+δ(Ge1−δ′−xGax)S4. No changes in the X-ray diffraction pattern were observed after 2 weeks for the surface of the pellets, which indicates no surface reaction.

Q: How were the cycling behavior of the electrolyte under polarizing conditions up to 5 V examined?
A: The cycling behavior of the electrolyte under polarizing conditions up to 5 V was examined using cyclic voltammetry. The current decreased gradually with cycling between 2 and 5 V, which indicates that no significant decomposition reaction proceeded with increasing cycling.

Q: What properties make continuous fibre-reinforced polymer matrix composites attractive for civil and transport structures?
A: Continuous fibre-reinforced polymer matrix composites possess relatively high stiffness and tensile strengths, low densities, and excellent impact and corrosion resistance properties compared to conventional materials like metals. This is why they are finding increasing application in civil and transport structures.

Q: What is the significance of scarf joints in the repair of engineering structures?
A: Among the configurations of adhesively bonded joints, scarf joints have been found to exhibit the highest structural efficiency. This is because joint eccentricities, which act as stress raisers, are minimized in the loading path, and a more uniform stress distribution is obtained across joints.

Q: Why is the understanding of the uniaxial tensile failure of neat polymer composites and adhesively bonded scarf joints of engineering alloys important?
A: The successful use of scarf joint configurations in practical applications depends on understanding the basic responses of these joints under uniaxial tensile loading. This understanding can help in predicting the joint strengths and understanding their failure mechanisms.

Q: What are the two failure modes observed in the experiments on adhesively bonded composite scarf joints?
A: Two failure modes were observed in the experiments (i) Mode A failure predominantly by fibre fracture and pull-out and (ii) Mode B failure predominantly by cohesive shear failure in the adhesive film with little or no fibre fracture and pull-out.

Q: How does the scarf angle affect the uniaxial tensile strength of the joint?
A: A clear scarf angle effect is evident, with smaller (i.e. shallow) scarf angles yielding higher joint tensile strengths in comparison to those with larger (steep) scarf angles. The knockdown in tensile strength was most prominent for scarf angles less than about 1°.

Q: How did the use of annealed aluminum end-tabs contribute to the testing process?
A: The annealed aluminum end-tabs enabled the knurled surfaces of the grips to ‘bite’ firmly into the specimen tabs, thus preventing slippage between the specimen and grips. They also distributed pressure applied by the grips evenly over the surface of the specimen, thus preventing local damage in the laminate.

Q: How did the finite element predictions of the scarf joint strength in uniaxial tension compare to the experimental values?
A: The knockdown in tensile strength with increasing scarf angle was well described by the finite element model predictions, which model the unidirectional composite as a homogeneous orthotropic continuum with Hashin–Lee composite laminate failure criterion.

Q: What technological applications do proton conducting solid electrolytes have?
A: Proton conducting solid electrolytes with high and pure protonic conductivity have a wide range of technological applications. This includes fuel cells, batteries, sensors, hydration/dehydration of hydrocarbons, electrolysers, and so on.

Q: Why are acceptor doped alkaline earth cerates and zirconates of interest?
A: They are of interest because of their possible applications as solid proton conductors.

Q: What is the significance of the chemical stability of barium cerates?
A: Barium cerates, e.g. BaCe0.9Y0.1O3 − δ, generally exhibit the highest proton conductivities; however, these materials are unstable at high temperature in the presence of CO2 and steam.

Q: What is the effect of doping barium cerates with trivalent cations?
A: Some of the zirconates show pure protonic conductivity in a hydrogen atmosphere at high temperature (600–1000 °C). However, significant differences exist in reported conductivities of zirconates, and n-type conductivity was found to be relatively high under reducing conditions in barium cerate and other cerates, while almost negligible in the zirconates.

Q: What is the application of semiconductor metal oxide gas sensors?
A: Semiconductor metal oxide gas sensors are promising candidates for monitoring Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) due to their many advantages such as simple manufacture technique, low cost, rapid response and recovery time.

Q: What is the critical issue limiting the wide use of metal oxide sensors?
A: The critical issue limiting the wide use of metal oxide sensors is the lack of selectivity towards different VOCs. It is difficult to distinguish each VOCs species due to their similar composition elements and molecular structure.

Q: How does the mixed oxide of SnO2–TiO2 doped with Ag ion improve the selectivity to VOCs?
A: The mixed oxide of SnO2–TiO2 doped with Ag ion improves the selectivity to VOCs by exhibiting special selective to each VOCs at different operating temperature.

Q: What is the significance of the optimum operating temperature for the sensor?
A: The optimum operating temperature for the sensor is crucial as it determines the sensitivity. As the operating temperature increases, the amount of gas adsorbed will reduce, and the balance will change to desorption, resulting in a decreased gas sensitivity when the operating temperature surpass the optimum values.

Q: How does the Lowest Unoccupied Molecule Orbital (LUMO) energy affect the sensing signal?
A: The LUMO energy is a qualitative factor that can affect the selectivity of the sensor. A lower LUMO energy would make the gas molecule possess the stronger ability in capturing electrons, stimulating the electron transfer between the gas molecule and the surface of the sensing material, and hence increasing the sensitivity of the sensor.

Q: How does the sensor respond to different VOCs?
A: The sensor exhibited remarkable selectivity to each VOCs such as ethanol, methanol, acetone and formaldehyde at different operating temperature. For example, at the low operating temperature about 280 °C, the sensor exhibits evidently response to ethanol as its lower LUMO energy.

Q: What is the potential use of this sensor in indoor air quality monitoring?
A: This sensor has the potential to be used in indoor air quality monitoring as it can distinguish different Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) species at different operating temperatures, a feature that could be beneficial in identifying and monitoring indoor air pollutants.

Q: What are the key properties of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) that make it a potential material of interest?
A: Polyvinyl Alcohol (PVA) is attracting attention due to its variety of applications because of its high dielectric strength, good charge storage capacity, and dopant-dependent electrical and optical properties. It has a carbon chain backbone with hydroxyl groups attached to methane carbons. These OH groups can form hydrogen bonds, assisting the formation of polymer complexes.

Q: What is the significance of titanium in various applications?
A: Titanium is of interest due to its optical, electronic, and UV-blocking properties. It also shows promise for self-cleaning, purification, and antibacterial applications.

Q: How does the addition of titanium chloride affect the dielectric behavior of polymeric films?
A: The study found that the addition of titanium chloride on dielectric behavior of polymeric films leads to a continuous decrease in the dielectric constant with increasing frequency. This suggests that the complexes are capacitive and can be represented by parallel RC networks connected in series.

Q: What is the correlation observed between the intensity of the XRD pattern and the degree of crystallinity?
A: The XRD pattern of pure PVA shows a characteristic peak for an orthorhombic lattice centered at 2θ=20° indicating its semicrystalline nature. On the incorporation of titanium chloride into PVA, the intensity of this peak decreases gradually, suggesting a decrease in the degree of crystallinity of PVA.

Q: How are the complexes represented in terms of their capacitance and loss tangent?
A: The complexes were found to be capacitive and could be represented by parallel RC networks connected in series, as indicated by the negative phase angle. The loss tangent (tan δ) decreased with increasing frequency for pure PVA and lower doped samples, but increased in higher doped samples.

Q: What impact does the doping level of TiCl3 have on the dielectric constant and AC conductivity of the PVA films?
A: The dielectric constant values, for undoped PVA, were found to be higher than those observed for doped PVA films. The increasing of dielectric constant values is due to the formation of newer complexes. The AC conductivity also increased rapidly at high frequency, driven by the movement of free ions.

Q: How are the relaxation times of the complexes affected by the titanium content?
A: The relaxation times were found to decrease with the increase of titanium content. This decrease may be attributed to the increase in mobility of ions in the polymeric matrix, resulting in decreased relaxation time.

Q: What is the significance of solid–liquid interfaces in various technological processes?
A: Solid–liquid interfaces have considerable technological relevance, with examples including lubrication and colloidal processes, biological and industrial processes. Changes in the liquid structure at the interface can have far-reaching implications.

Q: What experimental evidence exists to support the notion that the order is enhanced at interfaces by geometrical confinement?
A: Measurements of the surface force between two curved mica plates immersed in liquid have shown that this force is not monotonic, but contains oscillations as a function of plate separation. These oscillations are attributed to “structural forces” not contained in van der Waals-based models.

Q: What was the methodology employed to obtain the thin films of TEHOS?
A: TEHOS thin films were prepared by dipping silicon substrates into a solution of the liquid in hexane and then withdrawing them at constant speeds to ensure uniform film thicknesses.

Q: What was the primary method used to measure the reflectivity of the films?
A: The reflectivity of the films was measured using X-ray reflectivity, a technique that involves using X-rays to bounce off the surface of a sample and create a reflectivity curve.

Q: What are Patterson functions and what do they reveal in the data?
A: Patterson functions are used to analyze X-ray reflectivity data. They display secondary maxima, indicating density oscillations in the film without any fitting processes. The amplitude of these oscillations shows an inverse dependence on the width of the solid–liquid interface.

Q: How did the thickness of the films affect the reflectivity measurements?
A: Thicker films (>4000 Å) showed a visible interference pattern and were less susceptible to impurities during preparation. They also did not lose layer amplitude within a day like thinner films. Therefore, relatively thick films are good candidates for studying layering.

Q: What is the significance of the amplitude of the electron density oscillation in relation to the width of the solid–liquid interface?
A: The amplitude of the electron density oscillation shows an inverse dependence on the width of the solid–liquid interface. This means, the wider the interface, the lower the amplitude of the oscillations.

Q: What are the potential applications of polymer electrolytes?
