A: Fluorescence microscopy was used to obtain ex situ visualizations of water transport in the GDL. It provided useful information on how flow field flooding corresponds to operating conditions.

Q: What did the computational fluid dynamics (CFD) modeling reveal about the water transport mechanisms in the GDL?
A: The CFD modeling using the volume of fluid method showed that it is a combination of channeling with the growth of an interconnected dynamic network of water pathways within the GDL that dominates the mechanism of water transport.

Q: How does the GDL surface affect the behavior of droplets on it?
A: The GDL surface consists of randomly oriented carbon fibers with non-isotropic wettability. Droplets sitting on this highly rough surface experience fewer tendencies for detachment due to longer contact lines between the droplet and fibers and to the presence of contact angle hysteresis. Furthermore, residual water particles may also increase the tendency for droplet pinning.

Q: What are the key areas of research in anode materials for lithium-ion batteries?
A: The research on anode materials for lithium-ion batteries has primarily focused on finding carbon alternatives with larger capacities and better cycling performances. These materials include alloys with an active component and inactive components towards Li which act as a buffering matrix, amorphous tin-based oxides (ATCO), and layer structured materials such as Li3−xCoxN and Li3−xNixN.

Q: Can you explain the mechanism of the transition-metal oxides' usage as anode materials for lithium-ion batteries?
A: Transition-metal oxides, where M is Fe, Co, Ni, Cu or Mn, were found to have electrochemical capacities of about 700 mAh g−1 and excellent cycling performances. These oxides with rock-salt structure have no sites for the insertion/deinsertion of Li ions. However, a new mechanism was proposed wherein during the discharge, the MxOy particle is completely disintegrated into highly dispersed metallic nanoparticles (<10 nm) and Li2O matrix, and during the subsequent charge, the Li2O matrix decomposes and M nanoparticles convert back to MxOy nanograins.

Q: What is the significance of the content of nanoscale Ni in the NiO–Ni nanocomposite?
A: The presence of nanoscale Ni in the NiO–Ni nanocomposite facilitates the decomposition of Li2O and the SEI film during the charge process, which contributes to the composite's higher initial and reversible discharge capacity and better cycling performance compared to pure NiO.

Q: What is the role of the synthesized NiO–Ni nanocomposite in lithium-ion batteries?
A: The NiO–Ni nanocomposite serves as an anode material for lithium-ion batteries. It has a theoretic capacity of 718 mAh g−1 and exhibits capacities much higher than the theoretical value for NiO → Ni reduction. This indicates its excellent cycling performance.

Q: How were the structure and morphology of the synthesized products characterized?
A: The structure and morphology of the synthesized products were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD) and transmission electron microscope (TEM). The content of each element in the materials was analyzed using energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS).

Q: How were the working electrodes prepared for the experiments?
A: The working electrodes were prepared by a slurry coating procedure. The slurry consisted of 70 wt.% active materials, 15 wt.% acetylene black, and 15 wt.% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) dissolved in N-methyl pyrrolidinone (NMP), and was coated on a copper foam of 1.3 cm in diameter acted as current collector.

Q: What are the abrupt drop in potential and the long plateau in the discharge curves for the NiO–Ni composite and NiO electrode respectively attributed to?
A: The abrupt drop in potential down to about 0.6 V in the first discharge curve for each sample is attributed to the complete disintegration of the MxOy particle into metallic nanoparticles during the discharge process. The long plateau between 0.5 and 0.6 V is due to the formation of the SEI coating on the particles during the discharge process.

Q: How does the NiO–Ni composite behave between 0 and 3 V versus Li/Li+ at a current density of 100 mA g−1 in the first and second discharge?
A: In the first discharge, there is an extra capacity due to the formation of the SEI coating on the particles. In the second discharge, the plateau appears at about 1.25 V, which is higher than that of the first discharge.

Q: How is the cycling performance of the NiO–Ni nanocomposite compared to that of pure NiO?
A: The NiO–Ni nanocomposite exhibits much higher reversible capacities and much better cycling performance than the pure NiO. At the early stage of cycling, the reversible capacities of the NiO–Ni nanocomposite are higher than the theoretical value of NiO, which can be attributed to the presence of nanoscale Ni particles in the composite.

Q: What is the significance of sensitizers in the development of dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs)?
A: Sensitizers play a pivotal role in the development of DSCs. All the record performances of DSCs were achieved using some polypyridyl ruthenium dyes. In view of the limited ruthenium resource, metal-free organic dyes with a high molar extinction coefficient have attracted considerable attention in recent years due to their low cost and good flexibility in molecular tailoring.

Q: What was the efficiency achieved with an indoline dye in conjunction with a volatile acetonitrile-based electrolyte?
A: A very impressive efficiency of 9.5% was reached with an indoline dye in conjugation with a volatile acetonitrile-based electrolyte. However, the main challenge with this combination was the desorption of these indoline dyes from titania nanocrystals, even with several state-of-the-art stable electrolytes.

Q: Why is dihexyloxy-substituted triphenylamide considered a good donor in the construction of amphiphilic organic sensitizers?
A: Dihexyloxy-substituted triphenylamide is considered a good donor because it is feasible to purify and it can suppress charge recombination.

Q: How does the conjugation length impact the charge-transfer transition absorption?
A: Along with the increase in conjugation length, the charge-transfer transition absorption is not only bathochromic but also enhanced. This means that longer chain molecules experience stronger interaction with the light, enhancing the absorption capacity.

Q: What is the role of the bisthienothiophene unit in the C211 dye?
A: The bisthienothiophene unit in the C211 dye is linked to the dihexyloxy-substituted triphenylamide, and it extends the conjugation length of the dye. This unit is also expected to enhance the light-harvesting capacity of the dye.

Q: What were the key findings of the photovoltaic tests conducted on the C211 sensitizer?
A: The C211 sensitizer showed an efficiency of 6.5% under AM 1.5G sunlight in conjunction with a solvent-free ionic liquid electrolyte. The device exhibited excellent stability, keeping 92% of its initial efficiency after 1000 h full sunlight-soaking at 60 °C.

Q: What are the drawbacks of gel polymer electrolytes?
A: The main disadvantages of gel polymer electrolytes include poor dimensional stability, interfacial instability towards cathode materials, and lower liquid retention capacity.

Q: How are the properties of gel polymer electrolytes improved?
A: The properties of gel polymer electrolytes are improved by incorporating micro or nano-sized ceramic fillers. These fillers help preserve a porous structure that maximizes the adsorption of liquid electrolyte and reduce the risk of leakage.

Q: What is the role of the host polymer in gel polymer electrolyte nanocomposites?
A: The host polymer, such as Poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA), is chosen for preparing gel polymer electrolyte nanocomposites because of its good affinity with organic electrolytes, its amorphous nature, and its ability to exhibit high room temperature ionic conductivity values after the entrapment of liquid electrolytes.

Q: What is the function of the liquid electrolyte in the gel polymer electrolyte nanocomposites?
A: The liquid electrolyte, such as a 1.0 M solution of NaClO4 in ethylene carbonate (EC) and propylene carbonate (PC), is immobilized in the PMMA, and contributes to the ionic conduction process.

Q: How is the ionic conductivity of the gel nanocomposites evaluated?
A: The ionic conductivity of the gel nanocomposites is evaluated using impedance spectroscopy, and was found to be in the order of 10−3 S cm−1 at room temperature and 10−2 S cm−1 at 75 °C.

Q: What is the potential application of the studied gel polymer electrolyte nanocomposites?
A: The gel polymer electrolyte nanocomposites prepared in the study are promising materials for potential application in, for example, sodium batteries over a substantially wider temperature range.

Q: How is the electrochemical potential window of the gel nanocomposite evaluated?
A: The working voltage range for the gel polymer electrolyte nanocomposite was evaluated by cyclic voltammetry using stainless-steel electrodes, and the electrochemical stability was in the range from about −2.5 to 2.5 V.

Q: Can you explain how the SiO2 nanoparticles influence the electrical conductivity of the gel nanocomposites?
A: The addition of SiO2 nanoparticles induces a significant increase in the amorphicity of the nanocomposite materials, and thus enhances the electrical conductivity. It is also suggested that the SiO2 nanoparticles provide sites for anions to reside, thus enhancing the overall electrical conductivity.

Q: How does the thermal stability of the gel nanocomposites turn out?
A: The gel nanocomposites retain their gel-phase over a substantially wide temperature range of −80 to 140 °C, showing featureless DSC curves, which is advantageous for their potential application in electrochemical devices.

Q: What is the main promise of the redox flow battery (RFB) as an energy storage technology?
A: The redox flow battery (RFB) promises to be a low cost, high-efficiency large-scale energy storage system. It is seen as particularly promising due to its potential for use with renewable energy sources, which often have variable and intermittent output.

Q: What distinguishes the all-vanadium redox flow battery (VRB) and how is the problem of electrolyte cross-contamination overcome?
A: The all-vanadium redox flow battery (VRB) is notable for using only vanadium species for both halves of the cell. This overcomes the problem of electrolytes cross-contamination through the battery separator, which is a issue with other redox flow batteries.

Q: How does the module configuration affect the output power of a VRB stack?
A: The module configuration appears to have nearly no influence on the output power of the VRB stack. This means that the scale-up of VRB stack can be easily achieved by serial and/or parallel connection of stack modules to increase the output voltage and/or current, hence the output power.

Q: What are some of the key characteristics of a vanadium redox flow battery (VRB)?
A: Key characteristics of a VRB include two electrolyte loops, containing vanadium in a sulfuric acid medium, with different valence states that may be oxidized/reduced at the electrodes. The vanadium redox pairs are V2+/V3+ and V4+/V5+ for the negative and positive halves of the cell, respectively.

Q: How is the voltage distribution in a VRB stack characterized?
A: The voltage distribution in a VRB stack is fairly uniform, especially at lower states of charge (SOC) or state-of-discharge (SOD) and current density, indicating a fairly uniform distribution of the internal resistance, the reactant electrolytes from the electrolyte inlet to the outlet, and the activation polarization of the electrodes of unit cells in the stack.

Q: What were the results when a 10 kW VRB stack was constructed?
A: The 10 kW VRB stack exhibited excellent cyclic performance and stability of efficiency. A maximum energy efficiency of 82.35% for the 10 kW stack at the charge–discharge current density of 50 mA cm−2 was obtained.

Q: What are the fundamental physics processes that occur in a proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell?
A: The fundamental physics processes that occur in a PEM fuel cell involve coupled fluid flow, heat and mass transport, and electrochemistry. These processes require the simulation of multi-dimensional, coupled transport of reactants, heat and charged species using computational fluid dynamic (CFD) methods.

Q: How have CFD methods contributed to the development of PEM fuel cell models?
A: CFD methods have enabled the development of increasingly more realistic computational models of PEM fuel cells, accounting for fluid, thermal and electrochemical transport, complex three-dimensional geometries including flow and cooling channels, and two-phase transport (e.g. ).

Q: What are some of the challenges in modelling PEM fuel cells?
A: One of the challenges is the uncertainties associated with the specification of various parameters that impact the transport processes. Assessing the sensitivity of the flow, thermal or electrochemical response to these uncertainties is essential.

Q: What is the role of the catalyst layer in a PEM fuel cell?
A: The catalyst layer plays a crucial role in the functioning of a PEM fuel cell. It resolves the distribution of overpotentials at the electrodes, and accounts for non-uniform distributions of overpotentials.

Q: What is the impact of changing the conductivity in the gas diffusion layer?
A: Changing the conductivity in the gas diffusion layer can significantly alter the current distribution. It changes the relative influence of ohmic to activation overpotentials, thereby affecting the local current density.

Q: What is the significance of the asymmetry parameter in the Butler-Volmer equation?
A: The asymmetry parameter in the Butler-Volmer equation signifies the influence of the concentration and activation overpotentials on the reaction rate. Different values of this parameter can significantly alter the output of the fuel cell, making it a crucial factor to consider in modelling.

Q: How does the model resolve the catalyst layer?
A: The model resolves the catalyst layer by implementing a user-defined subroutine that takes account of the physico-chemical processes associated with PEM fuel cells.

Q: How does the model account for non-uniform distributions of overpotentials?
A: The model accounts for non-uniform distributions of overpotentials by using a parametric study that varies the asymmetry parameter, allowing for the prediction of physically representative distributions.

Q: How were the results from the model compared to experimental data?
A: The model's predictions were compared to polarization curves obtained from experiments or other models. While the model showed good agreement at low and mid-range current densities, it was noted that the model was unable to reproduce experimental data at high current densities. The discrepancy in this region was attributed to the assumption of single phase transport and the likely formation of liquid which would limit mass transport at higher current densities.

Q: Why was LiFePO4 proposed as an alternative to traditional cathode materials?
A: LiFePO4 was proposed as an alternative to traditional cathode materials due to its large theoretical capacity (170 mAh g−1), high safety, and low cost. However, its low electrical conductivity (10−9 to 10−10 S cm−1) had been a significant barrier to its commercial use.

Q: How does the carbon coating affect the electrical conductivity of LiFePO4?
A: The addition of carbon significantly improves the electrical conductivity of LiFePO4. Carbon provides good electrical contacts between LiFePO4 particles and the conductor in the cathode composite, thus enhancing the overall electrical conductivity of the material.

Q: How does the carbon coating affect the size of LiFePO4 particles?
A: The addition of carbon inhibits the particle growth during a sintering process, resulting in smaller particle sizes for carbon-coated LiFePO4. This was confirmed by SEM and HRTEM images, which showed that the particle size of the carbon-coated LiFePO4 was significantly reduced.

Q: What are the key improvements observed in the electrochemical properties of carbon-coated LiFePO4?
A: The carbon coating of the LiFePO4 particles decreased the resistances of Li-ion migration and charge transfer, improving the electrochemical properties of the cathode. The carbon-coated LiFePO4 showed higher specific capacity and better capacity retention compared to the bare LiFePO4.

Q: How is the capacity retention of the carbon-coated LiFePO4 during cycle tests?
A: The carbon-coated LiFePO4 exhibited excellent capacity retention without capacity fading. The reversible capacity was approximately 140 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C.

Q: How is the electrical conductivity of the carbon-coated LiFePO4 particles?
A: The electrical conductivity of the carbon-coated LiFePO4 particles was improved due to the addition of carbon. The carbon in the LiFePO4 provided good electrical contacts between the LiFePO4 particles and the conductor in the cathode composite.

Q: How was the crystal structure of LiFePO4 particles examined?
A: The crystal structure of the bare and the carbon-coated LiFePO4 powders were examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis.

Q: How did the addition of carbon affect the particle size of LiFePO4?
A: The addition of carbon inhibited the particle growth during a sintering process, resulting in smaller particle sizes for carbon-coated LiFePO4.

Q: What was the impact of carbon coating on the electrochemical properties of LiFePO4?
A: The carbon coating of the LiFePO4 particles decreased the resistances of Li-ion migration and charge transfer, allowing reversible electrochemical reactions during extraction and insertion of Li ions. This improved the electrochemical properties of the cathode and led to better capacity retention.

Q: What is the increasing use of biomass for energy paired with?
A: The increasing use of biomass for energy is often paired with a heated public debate, in which conflicting claims are made regarding its sustainability.

Q: What is the current global energy supply dominated by?
A: The current global energy supply is dominated by fossil fuels, which account for approximately 500 EJ per year, while biomass contributes approximately 50 EJ, making it by far the most important renewable energy source.

Q: Why is biomass expected to play a major role as a renewable energy carrier in the next few decades?
A: Biomass is expected to play a major role as a renewable energy carrier because of a wide variety of policy strategies and scenario studies that address future energy supply and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

Q: How does the use of biomass for energy affect greenhouse gas emissions?
A: The use of biomass for energy can reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, but the overall GHG balance depends on the crops used, the agricultural management, the co-products, and other factors.

Q: What is a key factor driving the use of biomass?
A: One of the main drivers for biomass use is to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.

Q: What range of energy potentials do biomass studies show?
A: Biomass potential studies show a wide range of energy potentials due to differences in methodologies and assumptions on crop yields and available land.

Q: What is the impact of large-scale biomass production on land use, agricultural commodity prices and agricultural productivity?
A: Large-scale biomass production can lead to changes in land use, which can affect agricultural commodity prices and agricultural productivity. It may also require large investments and many attempts at reclaiming degraded land for food production, which can present challenges.

Q: How does water availability impact biomass potentials?
A: Water availability can be a limiting factor for the production of biomass and food. The study showed that excluding water-scarce areas decreases the biomass potentials by about 15–25% for woody bio-energy crops in 2050.

Q: How does the use of degraded lands for biomass production affect potentials?
A: The potential of degraded lands—of which productive capacity has declined temporarily or permanently—to contribute to the production of biomass is not yet clearly assessed. However, using severely degraded land for annual crop production might require large investments and many attempts at reclaiming degraded land for food production have failed.

Q: How does the integration of biodiversity objectives influence the potential for bioenergy production?
A: The integration of biodiversity objectives is essential for sustainable biomass production. It is important to select appropriate bioenergy systems and apply adequate land use planning to ensure positive GHG balances and address environmental concerns such as biodiversity, soil quality, and water availability.

Q: What is the significance of electrochemical double-layer carbon supercapacitors (EDLCs) in sustainable transport?
A: EDLCs are key energy storage systems for sustainable transport based on hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs). Their high specific power and very long cycle life make them ideal for use in these applications. However, their specific energy is lower than that of batteries, so they do not yet fulfill the specific energy requisites for power assist in strong-HEV.

Q: What are the challenges with EDLCs?
A: Charging and discharging EDLCs can be a challenge due to their physical processes, which require a certain temperature range and low equivalent series resistance (ESR). The ESR affects the supercapacitor power performance, so it's crucial to develop materials and configurations that can increase C sc and V max without sacrificing cycle-life.

Q: Why are ionic liquids (ILs) considered for use in supercapacitors?
A: ILs are attractive because they feature high thermal and chemical stability, low vapor pressure, a wider electrochemical stability window than conventional organic electrolytes, and can operate in high temperature regimes that are not feasible with commercial systems.

Q: What is the main impediment to using ILs in symmetric EDLCs?
A: Symmetric EDLCs with PYR14TFSI electrolyte cannot be cycled with coulombic efficiency >95%, which is a requisite for long cycle-life, when the voltage is above 3.5 V. This limits their potential in this application.

Q: How do asymmetric EDLCs (AEDLCs) overcome the limitations of symmetric EDLCs?
A: In AEDLCs, each electrode can experience different potential excursions and be charged up to the ESW limits of the electrolyte, thus it's possible to increase V max without sacrificing cycle-life.

Q: What is the role of pseudocapacitive electrode materials in supercapacitor applications?
A: Pseudocapacitive electrode materials, which have significantly higher specific capacitance than carbons and can be charged/discharged several thousand times in aprotic IL by redox processes at potentials approaching the ESW limits, have the potential to increase the capacitance performance of supercapacitors without sacrificing V max and cycle-life.

Q: How do the AEDLCs and the HYSC-A system compare to commercial supercapacitors?
A: The AEDLCs and the HYSC-A system meet, and even exceed, the energy and power targets for power-assisted HEVs. Their high voltage and E max values suggest that they can compete with batteries and offer the advantage of inherently higher safety.

Q: What are the key properties of electrochemical supercapacitors?
A: Electrochemical supercapacitors are charge-storage devices that exhibit high power density, excellent reversibility, and long cycle-life compared to batteries. They come in two basic types

Q: What are the potential applications of supercapacitors?
A: Supercapacitors may be used in a variety of applications including load leveling for batteries in hybrid vehicles, burst power generation, and memory back-up devices. In hybrid vehicles, they supply energy during acceleration and hill climbing, among other activities.

Q: What is the significance of the electrode materials used in redox supercapacitors?
A: The electrodes of electrochemical redox supercapacitors consist of electroactive materials with various oxidation states. Transition metal oxides and conducting polymers with different oxidation states are considered promising materials for such applications.

Q: Why is the scan rate significant in the electrochemical deposition of EMD?
A: The scan rate is critical in the electrochemical deposition of EMD because it directly influences the properties of the deposited material. Higher scan rates, particularly when potentiodynamically deposited at high rates, have been shown to lead to the formation of microporous structures, which in turn can increase the specific capacitance.

Q: How is the specific capacitance of EMD affected by the cycle-life test?
A: The cycle-life test of EMD capacitors showed that there was a little decrease in the value of specific capacitance in the first 100 cycles. However, after 1000 cycles, a decrease of 10% of the specific capacitance was observed.

Q: What is the role of the method of preparation of EMD in increasing specific capacitance?
A: The method of preparation, such as the use of a high scan rate for the potentiodynamic deposition, leads to the formation of microporous EMD. This in turn allows the electrolyte to seep into the micropores, increasing the specific capacitance with the increase in thickness of EMD.

Q: What are the key components of a typical Dye-sensitized solar cell (DSSC)?
A: A typical DSSC consists of a porous TiO2 nanoparticle electrode and a Pt counter electrode separated by a liquid electrolyte containing I−/I3−. The nanoporous TiO2 is sensitized by a dye, which serves as a light-absorber.

Q: What is the significance of TiO2 nanofibers in DSSCs?
A: The use of TiO2 nanofibers in DSSCs improves the light harvesting efficiency without significantly sacrificing the dye attachment. This is due to the forward light scattering generated by the incorporation of TiO2 nanofibers, which increases light absorption.

Q: What is the challenge in improving the electron transport rate in DSSCs?
A: Overcoming the slow electron transport rate is a significant technological challenge in developing highly efficient DSSCs. This is due to the structural disorder where the surfaces of adjacent nanoparticles come into contact, leading to scattering of free electrons and reduction of carrier mobility.

Q: How does the composite of electrospun TiO2 nanofibers and conventional TiO2 nanoparticles improve the efficiency of DSSCs?
A: The composite made of electrospun TiO2 nanofibers and conventional TiO2 nanoparticles is an innovative type of photoanode that noticeably improves the harvesting of light without substantially sacrificing the dye uptake in DSSCs. This results in a higher energy conversion efficiency.

Q: How does the use of TiCl4 improve the electron transport in the TiO2 nanofiber–nanoparticle composite?
A: The TiO2 nanofiber–nanoparticle composite is post-treated with TiCl4 to improve the electron transport. The treatment increases the electron diffusion coefficient, leading to a 19% improvement in the charge collection efficiency.

Q: What was the impact of increasing the nanofiber percentage on the dye uptake?
A: If the nanofiber percentage was increased to 50 wt% or more, the dye uptake would be reduced by more than 30 wt%. This is due to the reduction in surface area as the nanofiber diameter increases.

Q: How does the composite affect the light absorption in the DSSC?
A: The composite made using the 15% nanofiber photoanode enhanced light absorption by up to 50% in the 600–800 nm region. This is due to the stronger scattering caused by the nanofibers.

Q: How was the improved Voc in the DSSCs explained?
A: The increased Voc in the DSSCs was mainly caused by the significant increase in JL, originating from the enhancement of light scattering. This increased absorbed light intensity, which led to a higher Voc.

Q: What is the alternative to conventional silicon-based photovoltaic devices that Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs) offer?
A: Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs) provide an alternative to conventional silicon-based photovoltaic devices, and are commonly used nanocrystalline TiO2 as a photoanode material. Other n-type metal oxide semiconductors like ZnO, SnO2, In2O3 and Nb2O5 can also be used, with ZnO being particularly expected to replace TiO2 due to its higher electronic mobility and similar energy level of the conduction band.

Q: How did the film morphology change during the CBD process?
A: The film morphology changed by controlling the solution chemistry for the CBD process. For instance, a nanocrystalline porous ZnO film was obtained by using an aqueous solution containing zinc nitrate hexahydrate and urea.

Q: How does the ZnO film's crystal structure change during the drying and heating process?
A: The X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the film just after drying is identified as a mixture of ZnO and layered basic zinc acetate (LBZA; Zn5(OH)8(CH3COO)2·2H2O). As the film is heated, it transforms again into single-phase ZnO.

Q: How does the ZnO film's optical properties change post dyeing?
A: The dyed ZnO film has a broad absorption band between 390 and 720 nm, corresponding to the absorption spectrum of N719. This indicates that the dye has been successfully loaded onto the ZnO film.

Q: What is the significance of the composite material system xLi2MnO3–yLi[Ni1/3Co1/3Mn1/3]O2–zLiNiO2 in the context of Li-ion batteries?
A: This composite material system has a high capacity, over 200 mAh g−1, and good structural stability at high charged state. It is also integral to the development of next-generation Li-ion batteries.

Q: How were the structural and electrochemical properties of the prepared materials studied?
A: The structural properties were identified using powder X-ray diffraction, and the electrochemical properties were evaluated using coin-type cells.

Q: What is the significance of the ratio xLi2MnO3–yLi[Ni1/3Co1/3Mn1/3]O2–zLiNiO2 in understanding the composite material's behavior?
A: The ratio xLi2MnO3–yLi[Ni1/3Co1/3Mn1/3]O2–zLiNiO2 is significant in understanding how each component contributes to the charge–discharge behavior of the composite material. Different compositions of this ratio can influence the material's performance.

Q: How does the initial charge capacity relate to the amount of LiMO2 in the composite structure?
A: The initial charge capacity below 4.45 V is strongly related to the amount of LiMO2 (y + z) in the composite structure. The increase of the initial charge capacity below 4.45 V was observed with the increase in the amount of y + z.

Q: How does the discharge capacity of the composite electrodes change with cycle number?
A: The discharge capacity of the composite electrodes shows a gradual increase during the initial 10 cycles. After 100 cycles, the capacity retention was excellent for some samples, while others showed rapid capacity fade.

Q: How does the compositional variation of the xLi2MnO3–yLi[Ni1/3Co1/3Mn1/3]O2–zLiNiO2 affect the rate capability?
A: The rate capability of the composite material varies with composition. Li[Li0.18Ni0.220Co0.120Mn0.480]O2 with x = 0.54 and y + z = 0.46 showed excellent capacity retention (95.6%) at 50 mA g−1 in the voltage range of 2.0–4.6 V and better rate capability than the other samples.

Q: What are the potential causes for the poor rate capability of Li[Li0.20Ni0.133Co0.133Mn0.534] at high current density?
A: The poor rate capability of Li[Li0.20Ni0.133Co0.133Mn0.534] may be due to a number of factors, including high polarization due to partially blocked Li diffusion pathway and the relatively large amount of irreversible loss of oxygen. Further studies are needed to understand these factors.

Q: What are the main advantages of lithium/sulfur battery?
A: The lithium/sulfur battery is very attractive due to its high theoretical specific capacity of 1675 mA hg−1-sulfur, assuming a complete reaction to Li2S. Moreover, elemental sulfur is very cheap, abundant and nontoxic material.

Q: What are the challenges in the commercialization of lithium/sulfur battery?
A: The main challenges in the commercialization of lithium/sulfur battery are low sulfur utilization and poor cycle life property. These problems are caused by soluble polysulfides that dissolve into the liquid electrolytes, causing the active material loss and viscosity increase of the liquid electrolyte as well as changes in the morphology of the sulfur cathode.

Q: Why are carbon nanotubes and nanofibers used in the lithium/sulfur cells?
A: Carbon nanotubes and nanofibers are added to the sulfur cathode to improve the electrical conductivity. They provide an effective electron conduction path and their network-like structure forms a structural stability of the sulfur cathode during charge/discharge process.

Q: How does the carbon coating affect the electrochemical properties of the sulfur cathode?
A: Carbon coating on the surface of the sulfur cathode increases the sulfur utilization due to the decrease of cathode resistance and the increase of specific surface area. It also enhances electrical contact and adsorbs lithium polysulfides, thereby improving the discharge capacity and cycle performance of the cell.

Q: What is the effect of carbon coating on the morphology of the sulfur cathode?
A: After carbon coating, the surface roughness of the sulfur cathode increases and sulfur particles are well covered with carbon particles. This can be considered due to the carbon coating layer.

Q: How does the Warburg diffusion change after 50 cycles?
A: After 50 cycles, the angle of the Warburg diffusion decreases due to the slow ion diffusion into the sulfur cathode by concentration increase of lithium polysulfides at the cathode-electrolyte interface.

Q: How is the discharge capacity of the carbon-coated sulfur cathode over time?
A: The discharge capacity of the carbon-coated sulfur cathode shows about 500 mA hg−1 at 50th cycle, which is two times larger than that of the no-coated sulfur cathode.

Q: How does the polysulfide adsorption by surface carbon layer affect the cycle life property of the lithium/sulfur cell?
A: It is suggested that inorganic additives such as Mg0.6Ni0.4O, Al2O3 and MWNTs give a beneficial effect on the improving cycle life property of lithium/sulfur cell because of their large specific area. The results of the study confirm this, suggesting that the polysulfides adsorption by surface carbon layer contributes to the increased cycle life of the cell.

Q: What is a multi-channel impedance spectroscope and how does it work?
A: A multi-channel impedance spectroscope is a device that allows simultaneous analysis of the impedance from half-cells or cells in a block or string. It works by enabling measurements of impedance in the mΩ range at frequencies from 6 kHz to a few micro-hertz.

Q: What are the challenges with using pure impedance data?
A: The paper indicates that pure impedance data is rarely sufficient for reliable results. This is because impedance spectroscopy results are often hard to reproduce or require very precisely defined operating conditions.

Q: How can impedance spectroscopy bring value in battery management systems?
A: Impedance spectroscopy can be valuable in battery management systems because it can provide continuous information about the state of the battery, including the state-of-charge (SoC) and cranking capability. This information is critical for developing reliable battery management systems.

Q: What are some of the challenges with SoC determination from a complete discharge–charge cycle?
A: The paper mentions that determining the state-of-charge (SoC) from a complete discharge–charge cycle can be expensive and time-consuming, and it may leave the batteries out of service during the testing time.

Q: How can impedance spectroscopy contribute to the improvement of battery cell design?
A: Impedance spectroscopy can help identify ageing processes in batteries and their evolution over time. This information can be valuable in improving battery cell design, as it provides insights into the battery's health and can help predict its future performance.

Q: What is the value of combining impedance-based elements with physics-based model elements in battery modelling?
A: The paper suggests that combining impedance-based elements with physics-based model elements can lead to highly precise hybrid models. This approach can help overcome the limitations of purely impedance-based models and provide more accurate simulations of real-world battery behavior.

Q: What are some of the projected applications of supercapacitors?
A: Supercapacitors are expected to be used as energy storage and delivery devices, complementing batteries. They can be used in hybrid arrangements with batteries or fuel-cells for electric vehicles, or as direct cold-starting energy reservoirs. Additionally, their high-power density but short duration electrical-energy pulses make them suitable for bridging short-period line power-outages.

Q: What is a significant barrier to the use of capacitors for energy storage?
A: A major challenge in using capacitors for energy storage is the need for them to be charged at high power densities, which can be impedance-ridden by real and/or equivalent resistance in series, known as ohmic resistance. This is in contrast to ideal capacitors, which can store appreciable charge-density and electrical energy density.

Q: How does the distribution of interconnected capacitative and ohmic elements impact the electrical charging and discharging behavior of porous electrode capacitors?
A: The distribution of capacitative and ohmic elements in the circuit impacts the power limitations that these effects introduce into the operating characteristics of capacitor devices. It can restrict the available power from the system on discharge or the reverse on charge, and the electrical behavior of the system corresponds to a power spectrum.

Q: What is the significance of Ragone plots in the technology of "hybrid" combination of electrochemical capacitors with high power-density (but relatively low energy-density) with high energy-density aqueous-electrolyte batteries for electric-vehicle drive trains?
A: Ragone plots represent the dependence of achieved energy-densities on operating power-densities. For electrochemical capacitors, the Tafel polarization terms do not normally arise, except with Faradaic pseudocapacitance at high rates. However, the operating voltage across the capacitor is dependent on the state of charge, which can systematically decline during discharge at constant current, more so than in the operation of many batteries.

Q: How does the distribution of internal electrolyte resistance impact the behavior of porous capacitor electrodes?
A: The distribution of internal electrolyte resistance impacts the charge acceptance and resulting limitations to operating power density. It is significant in the evaluation of porous electrode capacitors, especially those with non-aqueous electrolytes, where internal resistances are generally higher than with aqueous solution devices.

Q: What are some of the key factors that affect the energy density (e.d.) versus power density (p.d.) relations for electrochemical capacitors?
A: The Tafel polarization terms do not arise in the case of electrochemical capacitors, except with Faradaic pseudocapacitance at high rates. For these capacitors, the operating voltage declines with diminishing state-of-charge, systematically declining during discharge at constant current, more so than in the operation of many batteries.

Q: How does electrolyte concentration impact the performance of non-aqueous electrochemical capacitors?
A: In non-aqueous electrochemical capacitors, decreasing the electrolyte concentration below optimal levels enhances the distributed internal resistance effects, leading to power limitations. It also reduces the maximum power deliverable by the capacitor, effectively independent of resistance, and demonstrating the importance of optimal capacitor conditioning in system design.

Q: What is the implication of the continuous decline of output voltage in a charged capacitor during discharge?
A: The continuous decline of output voltage in a charged capacitor during discharge is an intrinsic property of a charged capacitor. This means that the voltage across the capacitor will systematically decline during discharge at constant current, more so than in the operation of many batteries except the Li–ion intercalation type where quasi-pseudocapacitance is exhibited.

Q: What are the key characteristics that an interconnect in a Solid Oxide Fuel Cell (SOFC) should possess?
A: An interconnect in an SOFC should exhibit excellent electrical conductivity, possess adequate stability in terms of dimensions, microstructure, chemistry and phases, especially under operating temperatures around 800–1000 °C. It must also have excellent imperviousness for oxygen and hydrogen to prevent direct combination of oxidant and fuel. Additionally, it should ideally have a thermal expansion coefficient (TEC) that matches those of the electrodes and electrolyte.

Q: What is the significance of the lowering of the operating temperature of SOFCs from 1000 to 800 °C?
A: The reduction in the operating temperature of SOFCs from 1000 to 800 °C enables the use of metallic alloys as interconnect materials. This is because metallic materials have higher electrical and thermal conductivities, are easier to fabricate, and generally have lower cost compared to ceramic interconnects.

Q: What role does chromium (Cr) play in the formation of a protective and semiconducting layer on the interconnect?
A: Chromium (Cr) is the most important element because of its formation of chromia as a protective and semiconducting layer. Chromium imparts oxidation resistance and changes the diffusion mechanism during the chromia scale formation from outward diffusion of the chromium ions to inward diffusion of the oxygen ions.

Q: What is the effect of reactive element oxides on the oxidation resistance of chromia-forming alloys?
A: Reactive element oxides enhance the oxidation resistance of all chromia-forming alloys. They essentially change the diffusion mechanism during the chromia scale formation from outward diffusion of the chromium ions to inward diffusion of the oxygen ions. This leads to reduced vacancies at the metal/oxide interface, decreased scale cracking, and improved electrical conductivity.

Q: How does the thermal expansion coefficient (TEC) of the alloys affect the suitability of an interconnect?
A: The thermal expansion coefficient (TEC) of the alloys is a critical factor in determining the suitability of an interconnect. The TEC of the interconnect must match that of other fuel cell components to avoid thermal stresses during start-up and shut down.

Q: How does the use of reactive element oxides affect the electrical conductivity of the oxide scale?
A: The use of reactive element oxides increases the electrical conductivity of the oxide scale. This is due to the formation of perovskite oxides, which have better conductivities than chromia, especially when doped with iron.

Q: How does the La2O3 coating affect the electrical conductivity of the oxide scale on Crofer 22 APU?
A: The La2O3 coating significantly improves the electrical conductivity of the oxide scale on Crofer 22 APU. For example, after 100 hours at 800 °C, the area-specific resistance (ASR) parameter for this coating is only 0.004 Ω cm2, which is much lower than the 0.1 Ω cm2 limit typically required for electrical conductivity.

Q: How does the Nd2O3 coating affect the oxidation resistance of the interconnect?
A: The Nd2O3 coating also provides an improvement in oxidation resistance. However, it's effect is not as significant as that of the La2O3 coating.

Q: What are the advantages of using MoO3 as an anode material in Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs)?
A: MoO3 has a superior theoretical specific capacity of nearly 1111 mAh g−1 which is three times the theoretical capacity of graphite. Additionally, it has a very stable one-dimensional (1D) layered structure which can act as a temporary support for intercalated species.

Q: What are the limitations of MoO3's electrochemical performance?
A: MoO3 has poor ionic and electronic conductivity which limits its electrochemical performance. This can be overcome by doping it with Na and Sn, modifying its structure, and incorporating it into composites.

Q: How does the initial coulombic efficiency of the bare MoO3 nanobelts change after carbon coating?
A: The initial coulombic efficiency of the bare MoO3 nanobelts increases from 67.57 to 85.80% after carbon coating. This indicates that the carbon coating enhances the charge transport on the surface of the composite electrode.

Q: How is the capacity retention and cycleability of MoO3 improved after carbon coating?
A: Carbon coating can enhance the electrochemical properties of the compound, effectively buffering the volume expansion and maintaining the structural integrity of the electrode. This improves capacity retention and cycleability.

Q: What are the two primary types of power interactions between vehicles and the electric grid?
A: The two primary types of power interactions between vehicles and the electric grid are grid-to-vehicle charging (G2V), which consists of the electric grid providing energy to the plug-in vehicle through a charge port, and vehicle-to-grid (V2G), where a vehicle has the ability to provide energy back to the electric grid.

Q: What is the direct, deterministic architecture in the context of V2G?
A: The direct, deterministic architecture is a V2G command and contracting architecture where individual vehicles bid and perform services while they are at the charging station. The vehicles leave the charging station, and the contracted payment for the previous full hours is made, ending the contract.

Q: What are the potential benefits of the aggregative architecture for V2G?
A: The aggregative architecture is proposed to be a more feasible and extensible architecture for implementing V2G ancillary services. It allows V2G to make use of the current market, command and control architectures for ancillary services and provides the grid system operator with a buffer against the stochastic availability of individual vehicles.

Q: What is the role of the aggregator in the aggregative architecture?
A: The aggregator is responsible for entering into contracts with the grid system operator on behalf of the V2G vehicles under its control. The aggregator can vary the size of its power contract based on the availability of vehicles at V2G-enabled charging stations, thus it is available to bid for ancillary services contracts at any time of day or night.

Q: How does the aggregative architecture improve the reliability of V2G ancillary services?
A: The aggregative architecture improves reliability by allowing the aggregator to manage the fleet size and contract size to maintain industry standard reliability over the course of each hour, day, and year. It can also vary the size of its power contract to maintain industry standards, even when vehicles are not present at the charging station.

Q: What is the impact of V2G on the electric grid?
A: The electric grid could assimilate a significant fraction of a hypothetical national fleet of plug-in vehicles performing G2V charging without significant infrastructure improvement and without centralized charging control. V2G provides the potential for the grid system operator to call on the vehicle as a distributed energy and power resource.

Q: What is the potential return on investment for owners of V2G-capable vehicles?
A: Previous studies have shown that there exists a significant return on investment for the owners of V2G-capable vehicles. This hypothesized return on investment has become a motivator for the implementation of V2G.

Q: What is the main challenge in predicting the lifetime of lead-acid batteries?
A: Predicting the lifetime of lead-acid batteries in renewable energy systems or autonomous power supply systems without extended laboratory tests is very difficult. This is mainly due to the fact that the cycling regime is very irregular, full chargings are rare, charging and discharging are intercepting each other frequently, and a wide range of charge and discharge currents occurs.

Q: How does the model handle corrosion in lead-acid batteries?
A: Corrosion means a conversion of the lead grid of the positive electrode into different lead oxides that form a layer with a complex structure on the grid. This leads to lower conductivity of the grid because of its reduced diameter and the increase in resistance across the corrosion layer between the grid and the active material. The corrosion products have a lower density and therefore a higher specific volume. This results in mechanical stress and therefore in a loss of active material because parts of the corrosion layer flake off and thus interrupt the contact between the grid and the active material.

Q: What is the impact of acid stratification on lead-acid batteries?
A: Acid stratification, which is the accumulation of acid at different levels in the battery, accelerates battery aging. It is fully reversible at any time if sufficient gas evolves or if electrolyte agitation systems are used. However, when acid stratification builds up during charging and discharging, it results in a gradient of the acid concentration, which can lead to uneven electric potentials and increased mechanical stress on the active material.

Q: What is gassing in the context of lead-acid batteries?
A: Gassing is a side-reaction in lead-acid batteries that occurs when the cell voltage is so high that hydrogen evolves at the negative electrode and oxygen at the positive electrode. The gassing current increases with increasing cell voltage according to a Butler-Volmer process, and with increasing battery temperature according to the Arrhenius law. It reduces the coulombic efficiency and results in mixing of the electrolyte.

Q: What is the role of the Shepherd equation in the model?
A: The Shepherd equation is used to calculate the cell voltage, which is decisive for corrosion and state-of-charge (SoC). It consists of four terms, including an open-circuit voltage at full-charge, a term associated with the change in open-circuit voltage with SoC, an ohmic loss term, and a term modeling the overvoltage as a function of current and SoC.

Q: How does the model handle the loss of active material in lead-acid batteries?
A: The model calculates the resistance of the corrosion layer and the capacity loss based on the corrosion layer thickness. It assumes that the effective layer thickness, or the loss of active material that is assumed to have lost contact, is correlated with the loss of active material that is caused by corrosion.

Q: What is the impact of degradation on lead-acid batteries?
A: Degradation represents the capacity loss caused by cycling of the battery. The IEC cycling lifetime is typically given in a datasheet and is related to the stage at which the battery is considered to have a remaining capacity of 80% compared with the nominal capacity. The number of nominal cycles is calculated by dividing the discharged Ah by the nominal capacity of the battery.

Q: How does the model handle the formation of sulfate crystals in lead-acid batteries?
A: The model assumes that the size of the sulfate crystals, and therefore the surface area, influences the dissolution of the crystals. Small discharge currents result in a lower number but larger lead sulfate crystals compared with those formed at higher discharge rates.

Q: How has the model been validated and what are its strengths and limitations?
A: The model has been validated using data from experimental lifecycle tests of two types of flooded lead-acid batteries. The tests consisted of a typical current profile of an autonomous power-supply system with either a wind generator or a photovoltaic generator. The model's predictions were found to be in good agreement with the measured values, demonstrating its accuracy. However, it is important to note that the model's accuracy is dependent on the quality of the data sheet information, and it cannot be better than that.

Q: What advantages does the use of alternative materials offer in PEMFCs?
A: The advantages of cheaper materials and simpler systems must not outweigh the disadvantages of any reduction of the power density. Usage of alternative materials like less noble metal catalysts, cheaper materials for the electrodes, cheaper and thinner membranes, and reducing the need for peripheral equipment such as gas humidification section and compressors can help reduce the cost and weight of the system.

Q: What is the role of the water transport in a PEMFC?
A: The water transport in a PEMFC is crucial for the power density of the cell. It can be adversely affected by too little water, i.e. drying-out, as well as by too much, i.e. flooding. The water transport in a PEMFC has been the subject of several studies, and it is essential to maintain a balance between these two extremes.

Q: How does the effective drag coefficient in PEMFCs relate to the water transport?
A: The effective or net drag coefficient in PEMFCs was measured for a wide range of conditions, involving gas humidification, temperature, pressure, current density and stoichiometry. The components of the MEA were varied, and the results were used for the selection of materials and operating conditions, but they will also be used as a basis for modelling, which will be the subject of a subsequent paper.

Q: What is the significance of electro-osmotic drag in the water transport in a PEMFC?
A: The electro-osmotic drag, together with the electrochemical production of water, results in an accumulation of water at the cathode/membrane interface. This can lead to dehydration of the anode gas, especially when dry gases are used. Therefore, it is essential to maintain a balance between these two forces to ensure optimal water transport.

Q: What factors determine the water transport in a PEMFC?
A: The water transport in a PEMFC is determined by the humidity of the inlet gases, the conditions that determine the humidity along the gas channel, i.e. stoichiometry, temperature, and pressure, and the thickness of the membrane.

Q: How does the thickness of the membrane affect the water transport?
A: The thickness of the membrane can significantly affect the back transport of water, which is the net drag coefficient in PEMFCs. With a thinner membrane, similar boundary conditions result in larger gradients across the membrane, which can lead to drying out of the membrane.

Q: What role does humidification play in the water transport in a PEMFC?
A: Humidification of the fuel inlet gas and oxidant (air) inlet gas play crucial roles in maintaining the water balance in a PEMFC. If these processes are not adequate, it can lead to dehydration of the cells, especially when dry gases are used.

Q: How does the cell performance react to changes in the humidity of the inlet gases?
A: The cell performance is very sensitive to the humidity of the inlet gases. Drying-out phenomena at the cathode side are much more detrimental for the cell performance than at the anode side. Therefore, it is crucial to maintain the humidity of the inlet gases to avoid performance losses.

Q: What is the effect of alternative electrodes on the water transport in a PEMFC?
A: The use of alternative electrodes, such as those from E-TEK and Toray, resulted in only a minor increase of the effective drag. However, it did help to reduce the cell voltage loss when dry air was fed to the cell.

Q: How does temperature affect the water transport in a PEMFC?
A: Temperature has a profound effect on the back transport, or the net drag, in a PEMFC. At higher temperatures, the back transport becomes smaller, and the effective drag decreases. This indicates that the gas conditions play a crucial role in the water transport.

Q: What is the challenge for new generation lithium-ion batteries?
A: The challenge for new generation lithium-ion batteries is to develop new cathode materials to replace the currently used material such as LiCoO2, which is expensive, toxic and has low capacity. Among several alternative materials, LiNiO2-based compounds have shown promising results in terms of lower cost and higher capacity.

Q: What is the main source of poor storage property of LiNiO2-based materials?
A: It was found that a 10 nm thin layer of Li2CO3 was formed on LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 particles after 2-year storage, which resulted in a much lower capacity than that of fresh ones. The formation of Li2CO3 during storage is usually attributed to the presence of H2O and CO2 in air that can adsorb on the material particle surface to react with lithium ions.

Q: What is the role of active oxygen species in the formation of surface species on LiNi0.8Co0.2O2?
A: Active oxygen species, such as O−, O2 −, etc., are likely formed on the oxide surface during storage, which can combine with CO2 to form absorbed carbonate species and with H2O to form hydroxyl species.

Q: How does nickel content influence the storage property of LiNiO2-based materials?
A: The poorer storage property of LiNiO2-based materials compared to LiCoO2 is largely attributed to the lower chemical stability of Ni3+ than that of Co3+ in the layered metal oxide framework. Reducing nickel content in the compound or replacing it with cobalt can suppress the reduction of Ni3+ to Ni2+ and thus effectively reduce the storage loss.

Q: How does exposure to air affect the structure of LiNi0.8Co0.2O2?
A: Exposure to air results in a reduction of Ni3+ to Ni2+ on the particle surface, accompanied by the formation of active oxygen species. These active oxygen species easily combine with H2O and CO2 in air to form adsorbed hydroxyl, carbonate and bicarbonate species.

Q: What techniques were used to analyze the surface changes on the cathode material of LiNi0.8Co0.2O2?
A: Several techniques were used, including thermal gravitometer (TG), scanning electron microscope (SEM), temperature programmed desorption-mass spectroscopy (TPD-MS), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and X-ray diffraction (XRD).

Q: What species were found to be the main surface species on the stored-in-air LiNi0.8Co0.2O2?
A: Adsorbed hydroxyl, bicarbonate, carbonate, crystalline Li2CO3, and NiO-like species were identified as the main surface species on the stored LiNi0.8Co0.2O2.

Q: How can the storage loss of LiNi0.8Co0.2O2 be recovered?
A: The storage loss of LiNi0.8Co0.2O2 can be recovered by a heat-treatment process. Heating the material at 725 °C in O2 flow can decomposes the adsorbed carbonate layer and re-oxidizes the NiO layer, thus achieving a full recovery.

Q: What is the ideal scenario for a 'smart' corrosion inhibiting coating?
A: The ideal scenario for a 'smart' corrosion inhibiting coating is for it to generate or release an inhibitor only when demanded by the initiation of corrosion. This would ensure that the inhibitor is effectively and efficiently used, and that the coating remains protected until it is needed.

Q: What is the role of natural passivity in regards to steel in nitric acid?
A: Natural passivity, such as the one that occurs for steel in nitric acid, allows the steel to use the naturally available driving force to synthesize a 'corrosion inhibitor', namely a compact oxide film.

Q: What is the concept of the doped PANI coatings on Al 2024-T3?
A: The concept of doped PANI coatings on Al 2024-T3 involves using inherently conducting polymer (ICP) films that hold an inhibitor only to release it when the film is coupled to a breach in the coating. This provides a 'smart' active coating that uses the energy inherent in the surface to be protected to produce an inhibiting material when called upon.

Q: What is the significance of organic corrosion inhibitors inhibiting the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR)?
A: Organic corrosion inhibitors have been shown to be effective at inhibiting the ORR, a key reaction in the corrosion process. Their ability to do so can help to significantly slow down or stop the corrosion process.

Q: What is the importance of the inhibition of the ORR by chromate and non-chromate inhibitors for the corrosion protection of high-strength aluminum alloys?
A: The inhibition of the ORR by chromate and non-chromate inhibitors is important for the corrosion protection of high-strength aluminum alloys. These inhibitors can help to prevent or slow down the corrosion process, contributing to the longevity and effectiveness of the coating.

Q: What is the alternative being developed to replace methyl bromide for soil fumigation?
A: The paper discusses the development of ozone generation technology using dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) as an alternative to methyl bromide for soil fumigation.

Q: What is the main benefit of ozone generation using DBD?
A: Ozone generation using DBD is beneficial due to its on-site generation, minimum human toxicity, and low persistent chemicals in the soil.

Q: How is the ozone concentration controlled in the experiment?
A: The ozone concentration is controlled by adjusting the applied voltage. The pyramid-type electrode can control the ozone concentration from low ozone concentration (0.1 g/m3) to high ozone concentration (12 g/m3).

Q: What is the impact of ozone treatment on soil sterilization?
A: Ozone treatment can lead to a significant reduction in microbial activity in the soil. In the experiment, Fusarium oxysporum, a soil fungus, was almost killed by ozone treatment of 20 g O3/m3 for 10 minutes.

Q: How does the screw-type electrode contribute to the ozone generation experiment?
A: The screw-type electrode is used to generate high ozone concentration with high efficiency. It can provide high ozone concentration (23 g/m3) with high efficiency (100 g/kW h).

Q: How does the pyramid-type electrode affect ozone generation?
A: The pyramid-type electrode initiates DBD discharges at a lower voltage of 1.7 kV compared to 3.5 kV for the screw-type electrode under the same conditions. The lowering of the voltage is due to the higher electric field strength of the pyramid electrode.

Q: How does the soil react to the injection of ozone gas?
A: The agricultural soil consisting of mud, sand, organics, minerals, and water shows a complicated change in physical and chemical properties after the injection of the ozone gas into the soil.

Q: What role does thermal spray technology play in the automotive industry?
A: Thermal spray technology is widely used in the automotive industry, particularly for coating transmission and engine parts. Some applications have reached maturity, while others represent a significant market for the future.

Q: What materials are used to coat transmission parts in the automotive industry?
A: Transmission parts such as synchronizing rings and shift forks are commonly coated using wire flame spraying with molybdenum to provide a constant coefficient of friction and prevent scuffing.

Q: How are piston rings coated in the automotive industry?
A: Piston rings are generally coated using the plasma spray process, and in the case of high performance piston rings for diesel engines, they may also be coated using the HVOF spray process.

Q: What is the significance of cast iron with vermicular graphite in the automotive industry?
A: Cast iron with vermicular graphite is used in high loaded diesel engines where higher mechanical strength and better toughness are required. It helps to reduce the weight of engine blocks.

Q: What role does silicon play in the production of aluminium cast alloys?
A: A high silicon content is required to secure the tribological properties of engine blocks made from aluminium cast alloys. The silicon content needed ranges between 17 to 20% by weight.

Q: What are the advantages and disadvantages of using hypoeutectic aluminium silicon cast alloys?
A: These alloys have the advantage of being lightweight and reducing the weight of engine blocks. However, they have poor tribological properties and require liners of cast iron with lamellar graphite or other surface treatments.

Q: What is the history of plasma spray coating in automotive engines?
A: The high thermal energy density available within the plasma used for melting the powder, coupled with the ability to manufacture powder and design plasma guns for specific applications with short spray distances, has rapidly promoted the use of plasma spraying in automotive engines.

Q: What are the key advantages of the plasma processes for coating engine blocks?
A: The plasma processes offer a high degree of freedom regarding the choice of coating materials, have a reliable melting process, and require low heat transfer to the engine blocks.

Q: How does the wear resistance of plasma sprayed coatings compare to cast iron?
A: The wear resistance of the plasma sprayed coating is significantly higher compared to cast iron. The wear rate in the critical area of the top position of a piston ring is about 5 nm per hour of service.

Q: How does the fuel consumption of engines with plasma coated liners compare to those with cast iron liners?
A: Engines with plasma coated liners allow a fuel consumption reduction of more than 2%. This technology presents a real alternative for this application and will continue to gain in importance primarily in Europe and Japan.

Q: Why have magnesium (Mg) alloys recently received significant attention as biodegradable implants?
A: Magnesium (Mg) alloys have been attracted because of their similar mechanical properties to natural bone and their ability to be degraded in vivo. This combination of advantages reduces the need for a second operation for removing and the long-term stress protection of the implants for bone repair, which are common with metallic implants like Ti alloy.

Q: How does the ion-beam assisted deposition (IBAD) method contribute to the creation of CaP coatings on Mg alloys?
A: The IBAD method is used to create CaP coatings on Mg alloys because it can make the coating have strong adhesion to the substrate and is easy to control the Ca/P ratio of the coating.

Q: What is the significance of annealing and immersion in deionized water as part of the post-treatment process for IBAD CaP coating?
A: Annealing at 250°C for 2 hours and immersion in deionized water at 100°C for 0.5 hours is part of the post-treatment process that helps to improve the mechanical properties and resistance to degradation of the coating.

Q: How does the hardness and elastic modulus of the AZ31 substrate change after the application of the IBAD CaP coating?
A: The hardness and elastic modulus of the AZ31 substrate increase significantly after the application of the IBAD CaP coating. The hardness increases from 1.24 GPa to 5.51 GPa (as-deposited coating) and 5.94 GPa (post-treated coating), while the elastic modulus increases from 33.42 GPa to 75.41 GPa (as-deposited coating) and 89.09 GPa (post-treated coating).

Q: How does the degradation behavior of Mg alloys with and without the CaP coating differ?
A: The CaP coating decreases the degradation rate of Mg alloys. In the accelerated test of degradation, the mass loss of coated samples was just one fifth of that of naked samples on the 15-day testing.

Q: What is the role of the annealing process in the IBAD CaP coating formation?
A: The annealing process results in a fine microstructure, which helps to improve mechanical properties and resistance to degradation.

Q: What is the significance of the phase structure of the IBAD CaP coatings?
A: The phase structure of the IBAD CaP coatings is analyzed using X-ray diffraction (XRD). The post-treated samples show the presence of hydroxyapatite (HA) peaks, indicating the successful transformation of the amorphous phase of the CaP coating into the crystalline phase.

Q: How does the IBAD CaP coating process affect the mechanical properties of the AZ31 substrate?
A: The IBAD CaP coating process significantly improves the mechanical properties of the AZ31 substrate. Before the coating, the AZ31 substrate had a hardness of 1.24 GPa and an elastic modulus of 33.42 GPa. After the coating, the hardness increased to 5.51 GPa and the elastic modulus increased to 75.41 GPa for the as-deposited coating, and to 89.09 GPa for the post-treated coating.

Q: What is the impact of the activation process, such as CdCl2 treatment, on the structure of CdTe solar cells?
A: The activation process, like CdCl2 treatment, can lead to the formation of statistically oriented large grains from small grains. It also results in the loss of the (111) texture in the sample, and large 3D grains are formed.

Q: How does the growth rate during film deposition affect the structure of CdTe films?
A: Varying the growth rate during film deposition can influence the structure of the CdTe films. Higher growth rates result in larger grain sizes and different morphologies.

Q: What is the role of the CdS layer in the process of creating CdTe films?
A: The CdS layer serves as a buffer layer and its deposition rate can affect the nucleation and growth of CdTe films. It is also important for absorber films for maximized lateral and vertical dimensions.

Q: How are the grains in CdTe films affected by the increase in sample temperature?
A: An increase in sample temperature, especially above 450°C, results in a mostly statistical orientation of the grains. At higher temperatures, there is a strong tendency to form pinholes and voids in the growing CdTe films.

Q: What is the impact of planar defects related to stacking faults and twin boundaries in CdTe films?
A: These defects, related to stacking faults and twin boundaries, contribute to the formation of low shunt resistances in the cell, due to pin-holes, unfavourable grain boundaries, and/or weak diodes. They are major losses in thin cells.

Q: How does the activation treatment affect the structural defects within the CdTe grains?
A: The activation treatment, like CdCl2 treatment, can lead to a loss of the defects related scattering intensity in the CdTe films. It also seems to safe to conclude that for the structural integrity of CdTe absorber layers, well-defined grains without planar defects are needed for optimal electronic properties.

Q: What is the relationship between film morphology and the formation of recombination pathways in CdTe solar cells?
A: The paper suggests that there is a strong tendency to form recombination pathways along grain boundaries and pinholes existing in the films, which lead to rather low parallel resistances and thus to a strong loss in performance of most CdTe solar cells and modules.

Q: How does the CSS deposition technique affect the structure of CdTe films?
A: The CSS deposition technique, used at low sample temperatures, tends to grow CdTe films in columnar layers with (111) orientation. Higher deposition rates result in larger grain sizes and different morphologies.

Q: What are the implications of the findings on the production of CdTe solar cells?
A: The findings suggest that films grown at lower temperatures by CSS may also provide good conversion efficiencies if the post-deposition treatment, especially the activation, is further optimized. Also, the films formed at these low substrate temperatures seem to provide advantages for the compactness of the absorber layer, which would be preferential for thinner solar cells.

Q: What is the main objective of the presented research?
A: The main objective of the presented research is to verify if pulsed-lasers are compatible with a damage-free machining process of CIS-based photovoltaic devices. The study compared the results obtained with nanosecond and femtosecond laser pulses to examine the micromachining performance as a function of laser pulse duration.

Q: How do the interaction of a laser beam with a solid target and the thermal properties of materials influence the micromachining process?
A: The interaction of a laser beam with a solid target is determined by its optical and thermophysical properties. The fraction of the laser energy that is absorbed by the material is determined by the absorptivity, and the absorbed energy per unit depth is determined by the absorption coefficient.

Q: How does the laser pulse duration affect the machining process?
A: For pulses of nanosecond duration, the laser can be considered as a heat source and a one-temperature model is used to describe the heat regime within the target material. However, for ultrashort laser pulses, a two-temperature model is required to take into account that electrons and lattice have different temperatures.

Q: What are the key factors that determine the ablation thresholds and ablation rates in the micromachining process?
A: The ablation thresholds and ablation rates are determined by the melting and evaporation thresholds of the material. These thresholds take into account the incident laser fluence and the material properties. For instance, in the case of femtosecond laser irradiation, the thresholds are computed using the two-temperature model.

Q: What is the role of the self-consistent model in computing the ablation rate?
A: The self-consistent model is used to compute the ablation rate of ZnO produced by 248 nm KrF excimer laser radiation. The model considers the laser beam absorption by the plume, and it's applied to model the expansion dynamics of the ablation plume, which is a crucial factor in the micromachining process.

Q: What are the findings regarding the use of nanosecond laser pulses in micromachining of CIS-based solar cells?
A: The study found that nanosecond laser pulses are compatible with the selective removal of the thin films of ZnO, CIS, and Mo. However, the use of nanosecond laser pulses causes damage to the solar cells, transforming them into ohmic resistances. This is attributed to the thermal character of nanosecond laser ablation, leading to the formation of a thick molten layer.

Q: What are the implications of the accumulation of metal residues on the walls of the ablation channel?
A: The accumulation of metal residues on the walls of the ablation channel is attributed to the mechanisms involved into material ablation with nanosecond laser pulses. The ablation plume interacts with the laser beam, and the ablated material is heated up, leading to the pressure generated by the laser-induced plasma. This pressure then pushes the liquid layer out of the center of laser–matter interaction, causing damage to the solar cells.

Q: What is the role of the femtosecond laser pulses in the micromachining process?
A: Femtosecond laser pulses of 100 fs pulse duration were used in the study to machine CIS-based photovoltaic devices without a relevant change of its photo-electrical properties. The use of ultrashort laser pulses is efficient in ensuring damage-free machining of CIS-based solar cells.

Q: What are some of the applications of transition metal oxides and nitrides?
A: Transition metal oxides have found applications in many industrial applications. They are used as architectural, antireflection, solar control, protective and automotive coatings, etc. Nitrides, such as TiN, NbN, ZrN, etc., are employed for chemically inert, hard and protective coatings.

Q: What drawbacks does the film deposition, especially for oxides, suffer from?
A: The film deposition, especially for oxides, suffers from several drawbacks such as a low deposition rate and arcing.

Q: How does the addition of nitrogen to the argon–oxygen atmosphere during deposition change the properties of the films?
A: The addition of nitrogen to the argon–oxygen atmosphere during deposition can increase the index of refraction. Such an increase is expected due to the polarizability of metal–nitrogen bonds being lower than that of metal–oxygen bonds, leading to a higher polarizability of the metal–nitrides.

Q: How does the nitrogen incorporation into the films affect the film density and deposition rate?
A: Nitrogen incorporation into the films should lead to an increase of film density, as the metal nitrides, in general, have a higher density than the corresponding oxides. The deposition rate increases significantly with increasing nitrogen flow.

Q: How does the deposition stress of the oxynitride films change with varying nitrogen flow?
A: The deposited films possess compressive stress as indicated by the negative sign. This stress increases further with increasing nitrogen flow and attains a maximum value for the films prepared with 100% N2 flow.

Q: How does the refractive index of the films change with nitrogen flow?
A: The refractive index of the films varies only slightly up to a certain N2 flow. Above the critical N2 flow the index of refraction increases significantly.

Q: What is the impact of the thermal expansion coefficient and film thickness between the film and the substrate?
A: The difference in both thermal expansion coefficient and film thickness between the film and the substrate can lead to large biaxial thermal strains being introduced into the films. This anisotropy of strain energy can serve as an additional driving force for abnormal grain growth.

Q: How are the grains expected to behave in a yielded polycrystalline film with FCC lattice after annealing?
A: According to the paper, in a yielded polycrystalline film with FCC lattice after annealing, the grains with lower average orientation factor (i.e., the grains with (1 1 0), (1 0 0), (5 1 1), and (2 1 1) planes oriented parallel to the plane of the film) are favorable.

Q: What is the impact of the effect of grain orientation on the yield stress?
A: Grain orientation influences the yield stress that a material can sustain. The paper suggests that the yield stress can be expressed in terms of the factor Chkl=sinΦcosΦcosλ, where Chk is the average orientation factor for a particular grain orientation.

Q: How are the strain energy densities of grains calculated in the context of the FCC metals such as Cu, Al, Ag, Au, Ni, Pb and Th?
A: The strain energy densities of grains are calculated theoretically, taking into account the grain orientation and the material parameters. The calculations include both elasticity and plasticity.

Q: What are the unique properties of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) that make them suitable for various scientific and industrial applications?
A: Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) exhibit remarkable mechanical, electrical, and thermal properties due to their unique structures. These properties make them suitable for a wide range of scientific and industrial applications, including but not limited to, use in polymer composites, biomaterials, and sensors.

Q: What is the purpose of incorporating functional groups on the surface of CNTs?
A: Incorporation of functional groups on the surface of CNTs is a subject that has been actively studied in CNT research. These functional groups can serve as anchoring sites for binding other materials, making them useful in various applications where CNTs are used.

Q: What method was used in the present work to modify the surface of CNTs and what was the purpose of the modification?
A: The NH3 plasma treatment method was used to modify the surface of the CNTs in this study. The purpose of this modification was to incorporate amino groups on the surface of the CNTs, which are useful as anchoring sites for binding other materials.
